column1: ap 03:00|3|"Writing in a diary is a really strange experience for someone like me. Not only because I've never written anything before
column2: but also because it seems to me that later on neither I nor anyone else will be interested in the musings of a thirteen-year-old schoolgirl. Oh well
column3: it doesn't matter. I feel like writing
column4: and I have an even greater need to get all kinds of things off my chest. ""Paper has more patience than people."" I thought of this saying on one of those days when I was feeling a little depressed and was sitting at home with my chin in my hands
column5: bored and listless
column6: wondering whether to stay in or go out. I finally stayed where I was
column7: brooding. Yes
column8: paper does have more patience
column9: and since I'm not planning to let anyone else read this stiff-backed notebook grandly referred to as a ""diary
column10: unless I should ever find a real friend
column11: it probably won't make a bit of difference.

column1: Now I'm back to the point that prompted me to keep a diary in the first place: I don't have a friend.
Let me put it more clearly
column2: since no one will believe that a thirteen year-old girl is completely alone in the world. And I'm not. I have loving parents and a sixteen-year-old sister
column3: and there are about thirty people I can call friends. I have a throng of admirers who can't keep their adoring eyes off me and who sometimes have to resort to using a broken pocket mirror to try and catch a glimpse of me in the classroom. I have a family
column4: loving aunts and a good home. No
column5: on the surface I seem to have everything
column6: except my one true friend. All I think about when I'm with friends is having a good time. I can't bring myself to talk about anything but ordinary everyday things. We don't seem to be able to get any closer
column7: and that's the problem. Maybe it's my fault that we don't confide in each other. In any case
column8: that's just how things are
column9: and unfortunately they're not liable to change. This is why I've started the diary. To enhance the image of this long-awaited friend in my imagination
column10: I don't want to jot down the facts in this diary the way most people would do
column11: but I want the diary to be my friend
column12: and I'm going to call this friend Kitty. Since no one would understand a word of my stories to Kitty if I were to plunge right in
column13: I'd better provide a brief sketch of my life
column14: much as I dislike doing so.

column1: My father
column2: the most adorable father I've ever seen
column3: didn't marry my mother until he was thirty-six and she was twenty-five. My sister Margot was born in Frankfurt am Main in Germany in 1926. I was born on June 12
column4: 1929. I lived in Frankfurt until I was four. Because we're Jewish
column5: my father immigrated to Holland in 1933
column6: when he became the Managing Director of the Dutch Opekta Company
column7: which manufactures products used in making jam. My mother
column8: Edith Hollander Frank
column9: went with him to Holland in September
column10: while Margot and I were sent to Aachen to stay with our grandmother. Margot went to Holland in December
column11: and I followed in February
column12: when I was plunked down on the table as a birthday present for Margot.

column1: I started right away at the Montessori nursery school. I stayed there until I was six
column2: at which time I started first grade. In sixth grade my teacher was Mrs. Kuperus
column3: the principal. At the end of the year we were both in tears as we said a heartbreaking farewell
column4: because I'd been accepted at the Jewish Lyceum
column5: where Margot also went to school.

column1: Our lives were not without anxiety
column2: since our relatives in Germany were suffering under Hitler's anti-Jewish laws. After the pogroms in 1938 my two uncles (my mother's brothers) fled Germany
column3: finding safe refuge in North America. My elderly grandmother came to live with us. She was seventy-three years old at the time.

column1: After May 1940 the good times were few and far between: first there was the war
column2: then the capitulation and then the arrival of the Germans
column3: which is when the trouble started for the Jews. Our freedom was severely restricted by a series of anti-Jewish decrees: Jews were required to wear a yellow star; Jews were required to turn in their bicycles; Jews were forbidden to use street-cars; Jews were forbidden to ride in cars
column4: even their own; Jews were required to do their shopping between 3 and 5 P.M.; Jews were required to frequent only Jewish-owned barbershops and beauty parlors; Jews were forbidden to be out on the streets between 8 P.M. and 6 A.M.; Jews were forbidden to attend theaters
column5: movies or any other forms of entertainment; Jews were forbidden to use swimming pools
column6: tennis courts
column7: hockey fields or any other athletic fields; Jews were forbidden to go rowing; Jews were forbidden to take part in any athletic activity in public; Jews were forbidden to sit in their gardens or those of their friends after 8 P.M.; Jews were forbidden to visit Christians in their homes; Jews were required to attend Jewish schools
column8: etc. You couldn't do this and you couldn't do that
column9: but life went on. Jacque always said to me
column10: ""I don't dare do anything anymore
column11: 'cause I'm afraid it's not allowed.""

column1: In the summer of 1941 Grandma got sick and had to have an operation
column2: so my birthday passed with little celebration. In the summer of 1940 we didn't do much for my birthday either
column3: since the fighting had just ended in Holland. Grandma died in January 1942. No one knows how often I think of her and still love her. This birthday celebration in 1942 was intended to make up for the others
column4: and Grandma's candle was lit along with the rest.

column1: The four of us are still doing well
column2: and that brings me to the present date of June 20
column4: and the solemn dedication of my diary.

column1: Now I'm back to the point that prompted me to keep a diary in the first place: I don't have a friend.
Let me put it more clearly
column2: since no one will believe that a thirteen year-old girl is completely alone in the world. And I'm not. I have loving parents and a sixteen-year-old sister
column3: and there are about thirty people I can call friends. I have a throng of admirers who can't keep their adoring eyes off me and who sometimes have to resort to using a broken pocket mirror to try and catch a glimpse of me in the classroom. I have a family
column4: loving aunts and a good home. No
column5: on the surface I seem to have everything
column6: except my one true friend. All I think about when I'm with friends is having a good time. I can't bring myself to talk about anything but ordinary everyday things. We don't seem to be able to get any closer
column7: and that's the problem. Maybe it's my fault that we don't confide in each other. In any case
column8: that's just how things are
column9: and unfortunately they're not liable to change. This is why I've started the diary. To enhance the image of this long-awaited friend in my imagination
column10: I don't want to jot down the facts in this diary the way most people would do
column11: but I want the diary to be my friend
column12: and I'm going to call this friend Kitty. Since no one would understand a word of my stories to Kitty if I were to plunge right in
column13: I'd better provide a brief sketch of my life
column14: much as I dislike doing so.

column1: My father
column2: the most adorable father I've ever seen
column3: didn't marry my mother until he was thirty-six and she was twenty-five. My sister Margot was born in Frankfurt am Main in Germany in 1926. I was born on June 12
column4: 1929. I lived in Frankfurt until I was four. Because we're Jewish
column5: my father immigrated to Holland in 1933
column6: when he became the Managing Director of the Dutch Opekta Company
column7: which manufactures products used in making jam. My mother
column8: Edith Hollander Frank
column9: went with him to Holland in September
column10: while Margot and I were sent to Aachen to stay with our grandmother. Margot went to Holland in December
column11: and I followed in February
column12: when I was plunked down on the table as a birthday present for Margot.

column1: I started right away at the Montessori nursery school. I stayed there until I was six
column2: at which time I started first grade. In sixth grade my teacher was Mrs. Kuperus
column3: the principal. At the end of the year we were both in tears as we said a heartbreaking farewell
column4: because I'd been accepted at the Jewish Lyceum
column5: where Margot also went to school.

column1: Our lives were not without anxiety
column2: since our relatives in Germany were suffering under Hitler's anti-Jewish laws. After the pogroms in 1938 my two uncles (my mother's brothers) fled Germany
column3: finding safe refuge in North America. My elderly grandmother came to live with us. She was seventy-three years old at the time.

column1: After May 1940 the good times were few and far between: first there was the war
column2: then the capitulation and then the arrival of the Germans
column3: which is when the trouble started for the Jews. Our freedom was severely restricted by a series of anti-Jewish decrees: Jews were required to wear a yellow star; Jews were required to turn in their bicycles; Jews were forbidden to use street-cars; Jews were forbidden to ride in cars
column4: even their own; Jews were required to do their shopping between 3 and 5 P.M.; Jews were required to frequent only Jewish-owned barbershops and beauty parlors; Jews were forbidden to be out on the streets between 8 P.M. and 6 A.M.; Jews were forbidden to attend theaters
column5: movies or any other forms of entertainment; Jews were forbidden to use swimming pools
column6: tennis courts
column7: hockey fields or any other athletic fields; Jews were forbidden to go rowing; Jews were forbidden to take part in any athletic activity in public; Jews were forbidden to sit in their gardens or those of their friends after 8 P.M.; Jews were forbidden to visit Christians in their homes; Jews were required to attend Jewish schools
column8: etc. You couldn't do this and you couldn't do that
column9: but life went on. Jacque always said to me
column10: ""I don't dare do anything anymore
column11: 'cause I'm afraid it's not allowed.""

column1: In the summer of 1941 Grandma got sick and had to have an operation
column2: so my birthday passed with little celebration. In the summer of 1940 we didn't do much for my birthday either
column3: since the fighting had just ended in Holland. Grandma died in January 1942. No one knows how often I think of her and still love her. This birthday celebration in 1942 was intended to make up for the others
column4: and Grandma's candle was lit along with the rest.

column1: The four of us are still doing well
column2: and that brings me to the present date of June 20
column4: and the solemn dedication of my diary.

column2: hi

column1: ""All's fair in love and war.""

column2: and it really made me feel good.

column1: Monday evening Hello came over to meet Father and Mother. I had bought a cake and some candy
column2: and we had tea and cookies
column3: the works

column7: ""Who do you like best

column1: He said

column4: I like Anne better

column1: In everything he says or does

column4: but he's more than that. Mother is also full of praise: ""A good-looking boy. Nice and polite."" I'm glad he's so popular with everyone. Except with my girlfriends. He thinks they're very childish
column5: and he's right about that. Jacque still teases me about him

column1: PROSPECTUS AND GUIDE TO THE SECRET ANNEX
A Unique Facility for the Temporary
Accommodation of Jews and Other
Dispossessed Persons"|"The Diary of a Young Girl"|"Anne Frank"
ap 11:20|eleven-twenty|"Dearest Kitty!
Mr. Dussel has arrived. Everything went smoothly. Miep told him to be at a certain place in front of the post office at 11 A.M.
column2: when a man would meet him
column3: and he was at the appointed place at the appointed time. Mr. Kleiman went up to him
column4: announced that the man he was expecting to meet was unable to come and asked him to drop by the office to see Miep. Mr. Kleiman took a streetcar back to the office while Mr. Dussel followed on foot.

column1: It was eleven-twenty when Mr. Dussel tapped on the office door. Miep asked him to remove his coat
column2: so the yellow star couldn't be seen
column3: and brought him to the private office
column4: where Mr. Kleiman kept him occupied until the cleaning lady had gone. On the pretext that the private office was needed for something else
column5: Miep took Mr. Dussel upstairs
column6: opened the bookcase and stepped inside
column7: while Mr. Dussellooked on in amazement.

column1: In the meantime
column2: the seven of us had seated ourselves around the dining table to await the latest addition to our family with coffee and cognac. Miep first led him into the Frank family's room. He immediately recognized our furniture
column3: but had no idea we were upstairs
column4: just above his head. When Miep told him
column5: he was so astonished he nearly fainted. Thank goodness she didn't leave him in suspense any longer
column6: but brought him upstairs. Mr. Dussel sank into a chair and stared at us in dumbstruck silence
column7: as though he thought he could read the truth on our faces. Then he stuttered
column8: ""Aber . . . but are you nicht in Belgium? The officer
column9: the auto
column10: they were not coming? Your escape was not working?""

column1: We explained the whole thing to him
column2: about how we'd deliberately spread the rumor of the officer and the car to throw the Germans and anyone else who might come looking for us off the track. Mr. Dussel was speechless in the face of such ingenuity
column3: and could do nothing but gaze around in surprise as he explored the rest of our lovely and ultrapractical Annex. We all had lunch together. Then he took a short nap
column4: joined us for tea
column5: put away the few belongings Miep had been able to bring here in advance and began to feel much more at home. Especially when we handed him the following typewritten rules and regulations for the Secret Annex (a van Daan production):

column1: PROSPECTUS AND GUIDE TO THE SECRET ANNEX
A Unique Facility for the Temporary
Accommodation of Jews and Other
Dispossessed Persons"|"The Diary of a Young Girl"|"Anne Frank"
> 18:00|"after 6 P.M."|"Open all year round: Located in beautiful
column2: quiet
column3: wooded surroundings in the heart of Amsterdam. No private residences in the vicinity. Can be reached by streetcar 13 or 17 and also by car and bicycle. For those to whom such transportation has been forbidden by the German authorities
column4: it can also be reached on foot. Furnished and unfurnished rooms and apartments are available at all times
column5: with or without meals.

column1: Price: Free.
Diet: Low-fat.
Runnina water in the bathroom (sorry
column2: no bath) and on various inside and outside walls. Cozy wood stoves for heating.

column1: Ample storage space for a variety of goods. Two large
column2: modern safes. Private radio with a direct line to London
column3: New York
column4: Tel Aviv and many other stations. Available to all residents after 6 P.M. No listening to forbidden broadcasts
column5: with certain exceptions
column6: i.e.
column7: German stations may only be tuned in to listen to classical music. It is absolutely forbidden to listen to German news bulletins (regardless of where they are transmitted from) and to pass them on to others.

column1: Rest hours: From 10 P.M. to 7:30 A.M.; 10:15 A.M. on Sundays. Owing to circumstances
column2: residents are required to observe rest hours during the daytime when instructed to do so by the Management. To ensure the safety of all
column3: rest hours must be strictly observed!!!

column1: Free-time activities: None allowed outside the house until further notice. Use of language: It is necessary to speak softly at all times. Only the language of civilized people may be spoken
column2: thus no German.

column1: Reading and relaxation: No German books may be read
column2: except for the classics and works of a scholarly nature. Other books are optional.

column1: Calisthenics: Daily.
Singing: Only softly
column2: and after 6 P.M.

column1: Movies: Prior arrangements required.
Classes: A weekly correspondence course in shorthand. Courses in English
column2: French
column3: math and history offered at any hour of the day or night. Payment in the form of tutoring
column4: e.g.
column5: Dutch.

column1: Separate department for the care of small household pets (with the exception of vermin
column2: for which special permits are required).

column1: Mealtimes:
Breakfast: At 9 A.M. daily except holidays and Sundays; at approximately 11:30 A.M. on Sundays and holidays.
Lunch: A light meal. From 1:15 P.M. to 1:45 P.M.
Dinner: Mayor not be a hot meal.
Mealtime depends on news broadcasts.

Obligations with respect to the Supply Corps: Residents must be prepared to help with office work at all times. Baths: The washtub is available to all residents after 9 A.M. on Sundays. Residents may bathe in the bathroom
column2: kitchen
column3: private office or front office
column4: as they choose.

column1: Alcohol: For medicinal purposes only.
The end.
Yours
column2: Anne

Breakfast: At 9 A.M. daily except holidays and Sundays; at approximately 11:30 A.M. on Sundays and holidays.
Lunch: A light meal. From 1:15 P.M. to 1:45 P.M.
Dinner: Mayor not be a hot meal.
Mealtime depends on news broadcasts.

Obligations with respect to the Supply Corps: Residents must be prepared to help with office work at all times. Baths: The washtub is available to all residents after 9 A.M. on Sundays. Residents may bathe in the bathroom
column2: kitchen
column3: private office or front office
column4: as they choose.

column1: Alcohol: For medicinal purposes only.
The end.
Yours

column1: THURSDAY
column2: NOVEMBER 19
column3: 1942"|"The Diary of a Young Girl"|"Anne Frank"

column1: ap 04:30|four-thirty|"Dearest Kitty
We don't really know how to react. Up to now very little news about the Jews had reached us here
column2: and we thought it best to stay as cheerful as possible. Every now and then Miep used to mention what had happened to a friend
column3: and Mother or Mrs. van Daan would start to cry
column4: so she decided it was better not to say any more. But we bombarded Mr. Dussel with questions
column5: and the stories he had to tell were so gruesome and dreadful that we can't get them out of our heads. Once we've had time to digest the news
column6: we'll probably go back to our usual joking and teasing. It won't do us or those outside any good if we continue to be as gloomy as we are now. And what would be the point of turning the Secret Annex into a Melancholy Annex?

column1: No matter what I'm doing
column2: I can't help thinking about those who are gone. I catch myself laughing and remember that it's a disgrace to be so cheerful. But am I supposed to spend the whole day crying? No
column3: I can't do that. This gloom will pass.

column1: Added to this misery there's another
column2: but of a more personal nature
column3: and it pales in comparison to the suffering I've just told you about. Still
column4: I can't help telling you that lately I've begun to feel deserted. I'm surrounded by too great a void. I never used to give it much thought
column5: since my mind was filled with my friends and having a good time. Now I think either about unhappy things or about myself. It's taken a while
column6: but I've finally realized that Father
column7: no matter how kind he may be
column8: can't take the place of my former world. When it comes to my feelings
column9: Mother and Margot ceased to count long ago. But why do I bother you with this foolishness? I'm terribly ungrateful
column10: Kitty
column11: I know
column12: but when I've been scolded for the umpteenth time and have all these other woes to think about as well
column13: my head begins to reel!

column1: Yours
column2: Anne

column1: SATURDAY
column2: NOVEMBER 2g

column1: Dearest Kitty

We've been using too much electricity and have now exceeded our ration. The result: excessive economy and the prospect of having the electricity cut off. No light for fourteen days; that's a pleasant thought
column2: isn't it? But who knows
column3: maybe it won't be so long! It's too dark to read after four or four-thirty
column4: so we while away the time with all kinds of crazy activities: telling riddles
column5: doing calisthenics in the dark
column6: speaking English or French
column7: reviewing books-after a while everything gets boring. Yesterday I discovered a new pastime: using a good pair of binoculars to peek into the lighted rooms of the neighbors. During the day our curtains can't be opened
column8: not even an inch
column9: but there's no harm when it's so dark.

column1: I never knew that neighbors could be so interesting. Ours are
column2: at any rate. I've come across a few at dinner
column3: one family making home movies and the dentist across the way working on a frightened old lady.

column1: Mr. Dussel
column2: the man who was said to get along so well with children and to absolutely adore them
column3: has turned out to be an old-fashioned disciplinarian and preacher of unbearably long sermons on manners. Since I have the singular pleasure (!) of sharing my far too narrow room with His Excellency
column4: and since I'm generally considered to be the worst behaved of the three young people
column5: it's all I can do to avoid having the same old scoldings and admonitions repeatedly flung at my head and to pretend not to hear. This wouldn't be so bad if Mr. Dussel weren't such a tattletale and hadn't singled out Mother to be the recipient of his reports. If Mr. Dussel's just read me the riot act
column6: Mother lectures me all over again
column7: this time throwing the whole book at me. And if I'm really lucky
column8: Mrs. van D. calls me to account five minutes later and lays down the law as well!

column1: Really
column2: it's not easy being the badly brought-up center of attention of a family of nitpickers.

column1: In bed at night
column2: as I ponder my many sins and exaggerated shortcomings
column3: I get so confused by the sheer amount of things I have to consider that I either laugh or cry
column4: depending on my mood. Then I fall asleep with the strange feeling of wanting to be different than I am or being different than I want to be
column5: or perhaps of behaving differently than I am or want to be.

column1: Oh dear
column2: now I'm confusing you too. Forgive me
column3: but I don't like crossing things out
column4: and in these times of

column1: scarcity
column2: tossing away a piece of paper is clearly taboo. So I can only advise you not to reread the above passage and to make no attempt to get to the bottom of it
column3: because you'll never find your way out again!

column1: Yours
column2: Anne

column1: MONDAY
column2: DECEMBER 7
column3: 1942"|"The Diary of a Young Girl"|"Anne Frank"

Hanukkah and St. Nicholas Day nearly coincided this year; they were only one day apart. We didn't make much of a fuss with Hanukkah

column3: we lit them for only ten minutes
column4: but as long as we sing the song
column5: that doesn't matter. Mr. van Daan made a menorah out of wood
column6: so that was taken care of too.

column1: St. Nicholas Day on Saturday was much more fun. During dinner Bep and Miep were so busy whispering to Father that our curiosity was aroused and we suspected they were up to something. Sure enough
column2: at eight o'clock we all trooped downstairs through the hall in pitch darkness (it gave me the shivers
column3: and I wished I was safely back upstairs!) to the alcove. We could switch on the light
column4: since this room doesn't have any windows. When that was done
column5: Father opened the big cabinet.

column1: ""Oh
column2: how wonderful!"" we all cried.

column1: In the corner was a large basket decorated with colorful paper and a mask of Black Peter.
We quickly took the basket upstairs with us. Inside was a little gift for everyone
column2: including an appropriate verse. Since you're famthar with the kinds of poems peo ple write each other on St. Nicholas Day
column3: I won't copy them down for you.

column1: I received a Kewpie doll
column2: Father got bookends
column3: and so on. Well anyway
column4: it was a nice idea
column5: and since the eight of us had never celebrated St. Nicholas Day before
column6: this was a good time to begin.

column1: Yours
column2: Anne

column1: PS. We also had presents for everyone downstairs
column2: a few things .left over from the Good Old Days; plus Miep and Bep are always grateful for money. Today we heard that Mr. van Daan' s ashtray
column3: Mr. Dussel's picture frame and Father's bookends were made by none other than Mr. Voskuijl. How anyone can be so clever with his hands is a mystery to me!

column1: THURSDAY
column2: DECEMBER 10

column1: Dearest Kitty
Mr. van Daan used to be in the meat
column2: sausage and spice business. He was hired for his knowledge of spices
column3: and yet
column4: to our great delight
column5: it's his sausage talents that have come in handy now.

column1: We ordered a large amount of meat (under the counter
column2: of course) that we were planning to preserve in case there were hard times ahead. Mr. van Daan decided to make bratwurst
column3: sausages and mettwurst. I had fun watching him put the meat through the grinder: once
column4: twice
column5: three times. Then he added the remaining ingredi ents to the ground meat and used a long pipe to force the mixture into the casings. We ate the bratwurst with sauerkraut for lunch
column6: but the sausages
column7: which were going to be canned
column8: had to dry first
column9: so we hung them over a pole suspended from the cethng. Everyone who came into the room burst into laughter when they saw the dangling sausages.It was such a comical sight. The kitchen was a shambles. Mr. van Daan
column10: clad in his wife's apron and looking fatter than ever
column11: was working away at the meat. What with his bloody hands
column12: red face and spotted apron
column13: he looked like a real butcher. Mrs. D. was trying to do everything at once: learning Dutch out of a book
column14: stirring the soup
column16: sighing and moaning about her broken rib. That's what happens when old (!) ladies do such stupid exercises to get rid of their fat behinds! Dussel had an eye infection and was sitting next to the stove dabbing his eye with camomile tea. Pim
column17: seated in the one ray of sunshine coming through the window
column18: kept having to move his chair this way and that to stay out of the way. His rheumatism must have been bothering him because he was slightly hunched over and was keeping an eye on Mr. van Daan with an agonized expression on his face. He reminded me of those aged invalids you see in the poor-house. Peter was romping around the room with Mouschi
column19: the cat
column21: Margot and I were peeling boiled potatoes. When you get right down to it
column22: none of us were doing our work properly
column23: because we were all so busy watching Mr. van Daan.

column1: Dussel has opened his dental practice. Just for fun
column2: I'll describe the session with his very first patient.

column1: Mother was ironing
column2: and Mrs. van D.
column3: the first victim
column4: sat down on a chair in the middle of the room. Dussel
column5: unpacking his case with an air of importance
column6: asked for some eau de cologne
column7: which could be used as a disinfectant
column8: and vaseline
column9: which would have to do for wax. He looked in Mrs. van D.'s mouth and found two teeth that made her wince with pain and utter incoherent cries every time he touched them. After a lengthy examination (lengthy as far as Mrs. van D. was concerned

column11: Dussel began to scrape out a cavity. But Mrs. van D. had no intention of letting him. She flailed her arms and legs until Dussel finally let go of his probe and it . . . remained stuck in Mrs. van D.'s tooth. That really did it! Mrs. van D. lashed out wildly in all directions
column12: cried (as much as you can with an instrument like that in your mouth)
column13: tried to remove it
column14: but only managed to push it in even farther. Mr. Dussel calmly observed the scene
column16: while the rest of the audience roared with laughter. Of course
column17: that was very mean of us. If it'd been me
column18: I'm sure I would have yelled even louder. After a great deal of squirming
column19: kicking
column21: Mrs. van D. finally managed to yank the thing out
column22: and Mr. Dussel went on with his work as if nothing had happened. He was so quick that Mrs. van D. didn't have time to pull any more shenanigans. But then
column23: he had more help than he's ever had before: no fewer than two assis tants; Mr. van D. and I performed our job well. The whole scene resembled one of those engravings from the Middle Ages entitled"" A Quack at Work."" In the meantime
column26: since she had to keep an eye on ""her"" soup and ""her"" food. One thing is certain: it'll be a while before Mrs. van D. makes another dental appointment!

column1: Yours
column2: Anne

column2: DECEMBER 13
column3: 1942"|"The Diary of a Young Girl"|"Anne Frank"

column2: and besides that
column3: the guns were booming away until dawn. I still haven't gotten over my fear of planes and shooting
column4: and I crawl into Father's bed nearly every night for comfort. I know it sounds childish
column5: but wait till it happens to you! The ack-ack guns make so much noise you can't hear your own voice. Mrs. Beaverbrook
column6: the fatalist
column7: practically burst into tears and said in a timid little voice
column8: ""Oh
column9: it's so awful. Oh
column10: the guns are so loud!""-which is another way of saying ""I'm so scared."" It didn't seem nearly as bad by candlelight as it did in the dark. I was shivering
column11: as if I had a fever
column12: and begged

column1: Father to relight the candle. He was adamant: there was to be no light. Suddenly we heard a burst of machine-gun fire

column3: to Pim's great annoyance
column4: lit the candle. Her resolute answer to his grumbling was
column5: ""After all

column5: the thieves disappeared
column6: and the only sound Mr. van D. could hear was the frightened pounding of his fatalistic wife's heart. ""Oh
column7: Putti!"" she cried. (Putti is Mrs. van D.'s pet name for her husband.) ""They must have taken all our sausages and dried beans. And what about Peter? Oh
column8: do you think Peter's still safe and sound in his bed?""

column1: ""I'm sure they haven't stolen Peter. Stop being such a ninny
column2: and let me get back to sleep!""

column1: Impossible. Mrs. van D. was too scared to sleep.
A few nights later the entire van Daan family was awakened by ghostly noises. Peter went to the attic with a flashlight and-scurry
column2: scurry-what do you think he saw running away? A whole slew of enormous rats!

column1: Once we knew who the thieves were
column2: we let Mouschi sleep in the attic and never saw our uninvited guests again. . . at least not at night.

column1: A few evenings ago (it was seven-thirty and still light)
column2: Peter went up to the loft to get some old newspapers. He had to hold on tightly to the trapdoor to climb down the ladder. He put down his hand without looking
column3: and nearly fell off the ladder from shock and pain. Without realizing it
column4: he'd put his hand on a large rat
column5: which had bitten him in the arm. By the time he reached us
column6: white as a sheet and with his knees knocking
column7: the blood had soaked through his pajamas. No wonder he was so shaken
column8: since petting a rat isn't much fun
column9: especially when it takes a chunk out of your arm.

column1: Yours
column2: Anne

column1: FRIDAY
column2: MARCH 12
column3: 1943"|"The Diary of a Young Girl"|"Anne Frank"

column1: ap 06:50|6.50|"Dearest Kitty
May I introduce: Mama Frank
column2: the children's advocate! Extra butter for the youngsters
column3: the problems facing today's youth-you name it
column4: and Mother defends the younger generation. After a skirmish or two
column5: she always gets her way. One of the jars of pickled tongue is spoiled. A feast for Mouschi and Boche. You haven't met Boche yet

column1: Her odd
column2: political name can easily be explained. For a while the firm Gies & Co. had two cats: one for the warehouse and one for the attic. Their paths crossed from time to time
column3: which invariably resulted in a fight. The warehouse cat was always the aggressor
column4: while the attic cat was ultimately the victor
column5: just as in politics. So the warehouse cat was named the German
column6: or ""Boche
column7: and the attic cat the Englishman

column1: VVe've eaten so many brown beans and navy beans that I can't stand to look at them. Just thinking about them makes me sick.
Our evening serving of bread has been canceled.
Daddy just said that he's not in a very cheerful mood. His eyes look so sad again
column2: the poor man!

column1: I can't tear myself away from the book A Knock at the Door by Ina Bakker Boudier. This family saga is extremely well written
column2: but the parts dealing with war
column3: writers and the emancipation of women aren't very good. To be honest
column4: these subjects don't interest me much.

column1: Terrible bombing raids on Germany. Mr. van Daan is grouchy. The reason: the cigarette shortage.
The debate about whether or not to start eating the canned food ended in our favor.
I can't wear any of my shoes
column2: except my ski boots
column3: which are not very practical around the house. A pair of straw thongs that were purchased for 6.50 guilders were worn down to the soles within a week. Maybe Miep will be able to scrounge up something on the black market.

column1: It's time to cut Father's hair. Pim swears that I do such a good job he'll never go to another barber after the war. If only I didn't nick his ear so often!
Yours
column2: Anne

column1: THURSDAY
column2: MARCH 18
column3: 1943"|"The Diary of a Young Girl"|"Anne Frank"

column1: ap 10:30|ten-thirty|"Dearest Kitty
Mother
column2: Father
column3: Margot and I were sitting quite pleasantly together last night when Peter suddenly came in and whispered in Father's ear. I caught the words ""a barrel falling over in the warehouse"" and ""someone fiddling with the door."" Margot heard it too
column4: but was trying to calm me down
column5: since I'd turned white as chalk and was extremely nervous. The three of us waited while Father and Peter went downstairs. A minute or two later Mrs. van Daan came up from where she'd been listening to the radio and told us that Pim had asked her to turn it off and tiptoe upstairs. But you know what happens when you're trying to be quiet-the old stairs creaked twice as loud. Five minutes later Peter and Pim
column6: the color drained from their faces
column7: appeared again to relate their experiences. They had positioned themselves under the staircase and waited. Nothing happened. Then all of a sudden they heard a couple of bangs

column9: while Peter went to warn Dussel
column10: who finally pre sented himself upstairs
column11: though not without kicking up a fuss and making a lot of noise. Then we all tiptoed in our stockinged feet to the van Daans on the next floor. Mr. van D. had a bad cold and had already gone to bed

column14: but heard nothing. Finally we came to the conclusion that the burglars had taken to their heels when they heard footsteps in an otherwise quiet building. The problem now was that the chairs in the private office were neatly grouped around the radio
column15: which was tuned to England. If the burglars had forced the door and the air-raid wardens were to notice it and call the police
column16: there could be very serious repercus sions. So Mr. van Daan got up
column17: pulled on his coat and pants
column18: put on his hat and cautiously followed Father down the stairs
column19: with Peter (armed with a heavy hammer
column20: to be on the safe side) right behind him. The ladies (including Margot and me) waited in suspense until the men returned five minutes later and reported that there was no sign of any activity in the building. We agreed not to run any water or flush the toilet; but since everyone's stomach was churning from all the tension

column5: and we still weren't sure what to expect. We were somewhat reassured by the fact that between eight-fifteen-when the burglar had first entered the building and put our lives in jeopardy
column6: and ten-thirty

column9: when there were still people out on the streets. Besides that

column11: it's easy to mistake the sounds. Besides

column1: So we went to bed
column2: though not to sleep. Father and Mother and Mr. Dussel were awake most of the night
column3: and I'm not exaggerating when I say that I hardly got a wink of sleep. This morning the men went downstairs to see if the outside door was still locked
column4: but all was well!

column1: Of course
column2: we gave the entire office staff a blow-by-blow account of the incident
column3: which had been far from pleasant. It's much easier to laugh at these kinds of things after they've happened

column1: Yours
column2: Anne

column1: PS. This morning the toilet was clogged
column2: and Father had to stick in a long wooden pole and fish out several pounds of excrement and strawberry recipes (which is what we use for toilet paper these days). Afterward we burned the pole.

The house is still trembling from the aftereffects of the quarrels. Everyone is mad at everyone else: Mother and I
column2: Mr. van Daan and Father
column3: Mother and Mrs. van D. Terrific atmosphere
column4: don't you think? Once again Anne's usual list of shortcomings has been extensively aired.

column1: Our German visitors were back last Saturday. They stayed until six. We all sat upstairs
column2: not daring to move an inch. If there's no one else working in the building or in the neighborhood
column3: you can hear every single step in the private office. I've got ants in my pants again from having to sit still so long.

column1: Mr. Voskuijl has been hospitalized
column2: but Mr. Kleiman's back at the office. His stomach stopped bleeding sooner than it normally does. He told us that the County Clerk's Office took an extra beating because the firemen flooded the entire building instead of just putting out the fire. That does my heart good! The Carlton Hotel has been destroyed. Two British planes loaded with firebombs landed right on top of the

column1: German Officers' Club. The entire corner of Vijzelstraat and Singel has gone up in flames. The number of air strikes on German cities is increasing daily. We haven't had a good night's rest in ages
column2: and I have bags under my eyes from lack of sleep.

column1: Our food is terrible. Breakfast consists of plain
column2: unbuttered brea and ersatz coffee. For the last two weeks lunch has been e. spinach or cooked lettuce with huge potatoes that have a rotten
column3: sweetish taste. If you're trying to diet
column4: the Annex is the place to be! Upstairs they complain bitterly
column5: but we don't think it's such a tragedy.

column1: All the Dutch men who either fought or were mobilized in 1940 have been called up to work in prisoner-of-war camps. I bet they're taking this precaution because of the invasion!
Yours
column2: Anne

column1: ap 05:30|five-thirty|"The Best Little Table
Yesterday afternoon Father gave me permission to ask Mr. Dussel whether he would please be so good as to allow me (see how polite I am?) to use the table in our room two afternoons a week
column2: from four to five-thirty. I already sit there every day from two-thirty to four while Dussel takes a nap
column3: but the rest of the time the room and the table are off-limits to me. It's impossible to study next door in the afternoon
column4: because there's too much going on. Besides
column5: Father sometimes likes to sit at the desk during the afternoon.

column1: So it seemed like a reasonable request
column2: and I asked Dussel very politely. What do you think the learned gentleman's reply was? ""No."" Just plain ""No!"" I was incensed and wasn't about to let myself be put off like that. I asked him the reason for his ""No
column3: but this didn't get me anywhere. The gist of his reply was: ""I have to study too
column4: you know
column5: and if I can't do that in the afternoons
column6: I won't be able to fit it in at all. I have to finish the task I've set for myself; otherwise
column7: there's no point in starting. Besides
column8: you aren't serious about your studies. Mythology-what kind of work is that? Reading and knitting don't count either. I use that table and I'm not going to give it up!"" I replied
column9: ""Mr. Dussel
column10: I do take my wsork seriously. I can't study next door in the afternoons
column11: and I would appreciate it if you would reconsider my request!""

column1: Having said these words
column2: the insulted Anne turned around and pretended the learned doctor wasn't there. I was seething with rage and felt that Dussel had been incredibly rude (which he certainly had been) and that I'd been very polite.

column1: That evening
column2: when I managed to get hold of Pim
column3: I told him what had happened and we discussed what my next step should be
column4: because I had no intention of giving up and preferred to deal with the matter myself. Pim gave me a rough idea of how to approach Dussel
column5: but cautioned me to wait until the next day
column6: since I was in such a flap. I ignored this last piece of advice and waited for Dussel after the dishes had been done. Pim was sitting next door and that had a calming effect.

column1: I began
column2: ""Mr. Dussel
column3: you seem to believe further discussion of the matter is pointless
column4: but I beg you to reconsider.""

column1: Dussel gave me his most charming smile and said
column2: ""I'm always prepared to discuss the matter
column3: even though it's already been settled.""

column1: I went on talking
column2: despite Dussel's repeated interruptions. When you first came here
column3: I said
column4: ""we agreed that the room was to be shared by the two of us. If we were to divide it fairly
column5: you'd have the entire morning and I'd have the entire afternoon! I'm not asking for that much
column6: but two afternoons a week does seem reasonable to me.""

column1: Dussel leapt out of his chair as if he'd sat on a pin. ""You have no business talking about your rights to the room. Where am I supposed to go? Maybe I should ask Mr. van Daan to build me a cubbyhole in the attic. You're not the only one who can't find a quiet place to work. You're always looking for a fight. If your sister Margot
column2: who has more right to work space than you do
column3: had come to me with the same request
column4: I'd never even have thought of refusing
column5: but you. . .""

column1: And once again he brought up the business about the mythology and the knitting
column2: and once again Anne was insulted. However
column3: I showed no sign of it and let Dussel finish: ""But no
column4: it's impossible to talk to you. You're shamefully self-centered. No one else matters
column5: as long as you get your way. I've never seen such a child. But after all is said and done
column6: I'll be obliged to let you have your way
column7: since I don't want people saying later on that Anne Frank failed her exams because Mr. Dussel refused to relinquish his table!""

column1: He went on and on until there was such a deluge of words I could hardly keep up. For one fleeting moment I thought
column2: ""Him and his lies. I'll smack his ugly mug so hard he'll go bouncing off the wall!"" But the next moment I thought
column3: ""Calm down
column4: he's not worth getting so upset about!""

column1: At long last Mr. Dussel' s fury was spent
column2: and he left the room with an expression of triumph mixed with wrath
column3: his coat pockets bulging with food. I went running over to Father and recounted the entire story
column4: or at least those parts he hadn't been able to follow himself. rim decided to talk to Dussel that very same evening
column5: and they spoke for more than half an hour.

column1: They first discussed whether Anne should be allowed to use the table
column2: yes or no. Father said that he and Dussel had dealt with the subject once before
column3: at which time he'd professed to agree with Dussel because he didn't want to contradict the elder in front of the younger
column4: but that
column5: even then
column6: he hadn't thought it was fair. Dussel felt I had no right to talk as if he were an intruder laying claim to everything in sight. But Father protested strongly
column7: since he himself had heard me say nothing of the kind. And so the conversation went back and forth
column8: with Father defending my ""selfishness"" and my ""busywork"" and Dussel grumbling the whole time.

column1: Dussel finally had to give in
column2: and I was granted the opportunity to work without interruption two afternoons a week. Dussel looked very sullen
column3: didn't speak to me for two days and made sure he occupied the table from five to five-thirty-all very childish
column4: of course.

column1: Anyone who's so petty and pedantic at the age of fifty-four was born that way and is never going to change.
FRIDAY
column2: JULY 16
column3: 1943"|"The Diary of a Young Girl"|"Anne Frank"

column1: ap 07:00|seven|"Dearest Kitty
There's been another break-in
column2: but this time a real one! Peter went down to the warehouse this morning at seven
column3: as usual
column4: and noticed at once that both the warehouse door and the street door were open. He immediately reported this to Pim
column5: who went to the private office
column6: tuned the radio to a German station and locked the door. Then they both went back upstairs. In such cases our orders are not to wash ourselves or run any water
column7: to be quiet
column8: to be dressed by eight and not to go to the bathroom
column9: and as usual we followed these to the letter. We were all glad we'd slept so well and hadn't heard anything. For a while we were indignant because no one from the office came upstairs the entire morning; Mr. Kleiman left us on tenterhooks until eleven-thirty. He told that the burglars had forced the outside door and the warehouse door with a crowbar
column10: but when they didn't find anything worth stealing
column11: they tried their luck on the next floor. They stole two cashboxes containing 40 guilders
column12: blank checkbooks and
column13: worst of all
column14: coupons for 330 pounds of sugar
column15: our entire allotment. It won't be easy to wangle new ones.

column1: Mr. Kugler thinks this burglar belongs to the same gang as the one who made an unsuccessful attempt six weeks ago to open all three doors (the warehouse door and the two outside doors).
The burglary caused another stir
column2: but the Annex seems to thrive on excitement. Naturally
column3: we were glad the cash register and the typewriters had been safely tucked away in our clothes closet.

column1: Yours
column2: Anne

column1: Bep has offered to get us some fruit

column3: gooseberries 70 cents a pound
column4: one peach 50 cents
column5: melons 75 cents a pound. No wonder the papers write every evening in big
column6: fat letters: ""Keep Prices Down!""

column1: I can assure you that when I went to bed at nine

column3: but I took no notice and leapt up
column4: wide awake

column2: I heard Mr. van Daan say
column3: and I thought everything had been stolen. But no
column4: this time it was wonderful news
column5: the best we've had in months
column6: maybe even since the war began. Mussolini has resigned and the King of Italy has taken over the government. We jumped for joy. After the awful events of yesterday
column7: finally something good happens and brings us. . . hope! Hope for an end to the war
column8: hope for peace. Mr. Kugler dropped by and told us that the Fokker aircraft factory had been hit hard. Meanwhile
column9: there was another air-raid alarm this morning
column10: with planes flying over
column11: and another warning siren. I've had it up to here with alarms. I've hardly slept
column12: and the last thing I want to do is work. But now the suspense about Italy and the hope that the war will be over by the end of the year are keeping us awake. .

Now that we've been in hiding for a little over a year
column2: you know a great deal about our lives. Still
column3: I can't possibly tell you everything
column4: since it's all so different compared to ordinary times and ordinary people. Nevertheless
column5: to give you a closer look into our lives
column6: from time to time I'll describe part of an ordinary day. I'll start with the evening and night.

column1: Nine in the evening. Bedtime always begins in the Annex with an enormous hustle and bustle. Chairs are shifted
column2: beds pulled out
column3: blankets unfolded-nothing stays where it is during the daytime. I sleep on a small divan
column4: which is only five feet long
column5: so we have to add a few chairs to make it longer. Comforter
column6: sheets
column7: pillows
column8: blankets: everything has to be removed from Dussel' s bed
column9: where it's kept during the day.

column1: In the next room there's a terrible creaking: that's Margot's folding bed being set up. More blankets and pillows
column2: anything to make the wooden slats a bit more comfortable. Upstairs it sounds like thunder
column3: but it's only Mrs. van D.'s bed being shoved against the window so that Her Majesty
column4: arrayed in her pink bed jacket
column5: can sniff the night air through her delicate little nostrils. Nine o'clock. After Peter's finished
column6: it's my turn for the bathroom. I wash myself from head to toe
column7: and more often than not I find a tiny flea floating in the sink (only during the hot months
column8: weeks or days). I brush my teeth
column9: curl my hair
column10: manicure my nails and dab peroxide on my upper lip to bleach the black hairs-all this in less than half an hour.

column1: Nine-thirty. I throw on my bathrobe. With soap in one hand
column2: and potty
column3: hairpins

column1: ap 05:30|Five-thirty|"Dearest Kitty
A new idea: during meals I talk more to myself than to the others
column2: which has two advantages. First
column3: they're glad they don't have to listen to my continuous chatter
column4: and second
column5: I don't have to get annoyed by their opinions. I don't think my opinions are stupid but other people do
column6: so it's better to keep them to myself. I apply the same tactic when I have to eat something I loathe. I put the dish in front of me
column7: pretend it's delicious
column8: avoid looking at it as much as possible
column9: and it's gone before I've had time to realize what it is. When I get up in the morning
column10: another very disagreeable moment
column11: I leap out of bed
column12: think to myself
column13: ""You'll be slipping back under the covers soon
column14: walk to the window
column16: sniff at the crack until I feel a bit of fresh air
column17: and I'm awake. I strip the bed as fast as I can so I won't be tempted to get back in. Do you know what Mother calls this sort of thing? The art of living. Isn't that a funny expression?

column1: We've all been a little confused this past week because our dearly beloved Westertoren bells have been carted off to be melted down for the war
column2: so we have no idea of the exact time
column3: either night or day. I still have hopes that they'll come up with a substitute
column4: made of tin or copper or some such thing
column5: to remind the neighborhood of the clock.

column1: Everywhere I go
column2: upstairs or down
column3: they all cast admiring glances at my feet
column4: which are adorned by a pair of exceptionally beautiful (for times like these!) shoes. Miep managed to snap them up for 27.50 guilders. Burgundy-colored suede and leather with medium-sized high heels. I feel as if I were on stilts
column5: and look even taller than I already am.

column1: Yesterday was my unlucky day. I pricked my right thumb with the blunt end of a big needle. As a result
column2: Margot had to peel potatoes for me (take the good with the bad)
column3: and writing was awkward. Then I bumped into the cupboard door so hard it nearly knocked me over
column4: and was scolded for making such a racket. They wouldn't let me run water to bathe my forehead
column5: so now I'm walking around with a giant lump over my right eye. To make matters worse
column6: the little toe on my right foot got stuck in the vacuum cleaner. It bled and hurt
column7: but my other ailments were already causing me so much trouble that I let this one slide
column8: which was stupid of me
column9: because now I'm walking around with an infected toe. What with the salve
column10: the gauze and the tape
column11: I can't get my heavenly new shoe on my foot.

column1: Dussel has put us in danger for the umpteenth time. He actually had Miep bring him a book
column2: an anti-Mussolini tirade
column3: which has been banned. On the way here she was knocked down by an SS motorcycle. She lost her head and shouted ""You brutes!"" and went on her way. I don't dare think what would have happened if she'd been taken down to headquarters.

column1: Yours
column2: Anne

column1: A Daily Chore in Our Little Community: Peeling Potatoes!
One person goes to get some newspapers; another
column2: the knives (keeping the best for himself
column3: of course); the third
column4: the potatoes; and the fourth
column5: the water. Mr. Dussel begins. He may not always peel them very well
column6: but he does peel nonstop
column7: glancing left and right to see if everyone is doing it the way he does. No
column8: they're not!

column1: ""Look
column2: Anne
column3: I am taking peeler in my hand like so and going from the top to bottom! Nein
column4: not so . . . but so!""

column1: ""I think my way is easier
column2: Mr. Dussel
column3: I say tentatively.

column1: ""But this is best way
column2: Anne. This you can take from me. Of course
column3: it is no matter
column4: you do the way you want.""

column1: We go on peeling. I glance at Dussel out of the corner of my eye. Lost in thought
column2: he shakes his head (over me
column3: no doubt)
column4: but says no more. I keep on peeling. Then I look at Father
column5: on the other side of me. To Father
column6: peeling potatoes is not a chore
column7: but precision work. When he reads
column8: he has a deep wrinkle in the back of his head. But when he's preparing potatoes
column9: beans or vegetables
column10: he seems to be totally absorbed in his task. He puts on his potato-peeling face
column11: and when it's set in that particular way
column12: it would be impossible for him to turn out anything less than a perfectly peeled potato. I keep on working. I glance up for a second
column13: but that's all the time I need. Mrs. van D. is trying to attract Dussel's attention. She starts by looking in his direction
column14: but Dussel pretends not to notice. She winks
column15: but Dussel goes on peeling. She laughs
column16: but Dussel still doesn't look up. Then Mother laughs too
column17: but Dussel pays them no mind. Having failed to achieve her goal
column18: Mrs. van D. is obliged to change tactics. There's a brief silence. Then she says
column19: ""Putti
column20: why don't you put on an apron? Otherwise
column21: I'll have to spend all day tomorrow trying to get the spots out of your suit!""

column1: ""I'm not getting it dirty.""
Another brief silence. ""Putti
column2: why don't you sit down?'

column1: ""I'm fine this way. I like standing up!""
Silence.
""Putti
column2: look out
column3: du spritzt schon!"".* [*Now you're splashing!]

column1: ""I know
column2: Mommy
column3: but I'm being careful.""

column1: Mrs. van D. casts about for another topic. ""Tell me
column2: Putti
column3: why aren't the British carrying out any bombing raids today?""

column1: ""Because the weather's bad
column2: Kerli!""

column1: ""But yesterday it was such nice weather and they weren't flying then either."" ""Let's drop the subject.""
""Why? Can't a person talk about that or offer an opinion?'
""Well
column2: why in the world not?""

column1: ""Oh
column2: be quiet
column3: Mammichen!""* [*Mommy]

column1: ""Mr. Frank always answers his wife.""
Mr. van D. is trying to control himself. This remark always rubs him the wrong way
column2: but Mrs. van D.'s not one to quit: ""Oh
column3: there's never going to be an invasion!""

column1: Mr. van D. turns white
column2: and when she notices it
column3: Mrs. van D. turns red
column4: but she's not about to be deterred: ""The British aren't doing a thing!"" The bomb bursts. ""And now shut up
column5: Donnerwetter noch mal!* [*For crying out loud!""]

column1: Mother can barely stifle a laugh
column2: and I stare straight ahead.

column1: Scenes like these are repeated almost daily
column2: unless they've just had a terrible fight. In that case
column3: neither Mr. nor Mrs. van D. says a word.

column1: It's time for me to get some more potatoes. I go up to the attic
column2: where Peter is busy picking fleas from the cat.

column1: He looks up
column2: the cat notices it
column3: and whoosh. . . he's gone. Out the window and into the rain gutter.

column1: Peter swears; I laugh and slip out of the room.
Freedom in the Annex
Five-thirty. Bep's arrival signals the beginning of our nightly freedom. Things get going right away. I go upstairs with Bep
column2: who usually has her dessert before the rest of us. The moment she sits down
column3: Mrs. van D. begins stating her wishes. Her list usually starts with ""Oh
column4: by the way
column5: Bep
column6: something else I'd like. . ."" Bep winks at me. Mrs. van D. doesn't miss a chance to make her wishes known to whoever comes upstairs. It must be one of the reasons none of them like to go up there.

column1: Five forty-five. Bep leaves. I go down two floors to have a look around: first to the kitchen
column2: then to the private office and then to the coal bin to open the cat door for Mouschi.

column1: After a long tour of inspection
column2: I wind up in Mr. Kugler's office. Mr. van Daan is combing all the drawers and files for today's mail. Peter picks up Boche and the warehouse key; Pim lugs the typewriters upstairs; Margot looks around for a quiet place to do her office work; Mrs. van D. puts a kettle of water on the stove; Mother comes down the stairs with a pan of potatoes; we all know our jobs.

column1: Soon Peter comes back from the warehouse. The first question they ask him is whether he's remembered the bread. No
column2: he hasn't. He crouches before the door to the front office to make himself as small as possible and crawls on his hands and knees to the steel cabinet
column3: takes out the bread and starts to leave. At any rate
column4: that's what he intends to do
column5: but before he knows what's happened
column6: Mouschi has jumped over him and gone to sit under the desk.

column1: Peter looks all around him. Aha

column8: an hour and fifteen minutes ago

column1: ""God Save the King

column3: the Dutch program was uplifting without being too optimistic.

column1: The British have landed in Naples. Northern Italy is occupied by the Germans. The truce was signed on Friday
column2: September 3
column3: the day the British landed in Italy. The Germans are ranting and raving in all the newspapers at the treachery of Badoglio and the Italian king.

column3: we all like him very much. He's unfailingly cheerful and amazingly brave
column4: despite the fact that he's always sick and in pain and can't eat much or do a lot of walking. ""When Mr. Kleiman enters a room

column9: but we've almost forgotten how to laugh. Sometimes I'm afraid my face is going to sag with all this sorrow and that my mouth is going to permanently droop at the corners. column1: You mustn't think I'm in love with Peter
column2: because I'm not. If the van Daans had had a daughter instead of a son
column3: I'd have tried to make friends with her. This morning I woke up just before seven and immediately remembered what I'd been dreaming about. I was sitting on a chair and across from me was Peter. . . Peter Schiff. We were looking at a book of drawings by Mary Bos. The dream was so vivid I can even remember some of the drawings. But that wasn't all-the dream went on. Peter's eyes suddenly met mine
column4: and I stared for a long time into those velvety brown eyes. Then he said very softly
column5: ""If I'd only known
column6: I'd have come to you long ago!"" I turned abruptly away
column7: overcome by emotion. And then I felt a soft
column8: oh-so-cool and gentle cheek against mine
column9: and it felt so good
column10: so good . . .

column1: At that point I woke up
column2: still feeling his cheek against mine and his brown eyes staring deep into my heart
column3: so deep that he could read how much I'd loved him and how much I still do. Again my eyes filled with tears
column4: and I was sad because I'd lost him once more
column5: and yet at the same time glad because I knew with certainty that Peter is still the only one for me. '

column1: It's funny
column2: but I often have such vivid images in my dreams. One night I saw Grammy* [*Grammy is Anne's grandmother on her father's side
column3: and Grandma her grandmother on her mother's side.] so clearly that I could even make out her skin of soft
column4: crinkly velvet. Another time Grandma appeared to me as a guardian angel. After that it was Hanneli
column5: who still symbolizes to me the suffering of my friends as well as that of Jews in general
column6: so that when I'm praying for her
column7: I'm also praying for all the Jews and all those in need.

column1: And now Peter
column2: my dearest Peter. I've never had such a clear mental image of him. I don't need a photograph
column3: I can see him oh so well.

column1: Yours
column2: Anne

column1: FRIDAY
column2: ]ANUARY 7

column1: Dearest Kitty
I'm such an idiot. I forgot that I haven't yet told you the story of my one true love.
When I was a little girl
column2: way back in kindergarten
column3: I took a liking to Sally Kimmel. His father was gone
column4: and he and his mother lived with an aunt. One of Sally's cousins was a good-looking
column5: slender
column6: dark-haired boy named Appy
column7: who later turned out to look like a movie idol and aroused more admiration than the short
column8: comical
column9: chubby Sally. For a long time we went everywhere together
column10: but aside from that
column11: my love was unrequited until Peter crossed my path. I had an out-and-out crush on him. He liked me too
column12: and we were inseparable for one whole summer. I can still see us walking hand in hand through our neighborhood
column13: Peter in a white cotton suit and me in a short summer dress. At the end of the summer vacation he went to the seventh grade at the middle school
column14: while I was in the sixth grade at the grammar school. He'd pick me up on the way home
column15: or I'd pick him up. Peter was the ideal boy: tall
column17: with a serious
column18: quiet and intelligent face. He had dark hair
column19: beautiful brown eyes
column20: ruddy cheeks and a nicely pointed nose. I was crazy about his smile
column21: which made him look so boyish and mischievous.

column1: I'd gone away to the countryside during summer vacation
column2: and when I came back
column3: Peter was no longer at his old address; he'd moved and was living with a much older boy
column4: who apparently told him I was just a kid
column5: because Peter stopped seeing me. I loved him so much that I didn't want to face the truth. I kept clinging to him until the day I finally realized that if I continued to chase after him
column6: people would say I was boy-crazy.

column1: The years went by. Peter hung around with girls his own age and no longer bothered to say hello to me. I started school at the Jewish Lyceum
column2: and several boys in my class were in love with me. I enjoyed it and felt honored by their attentions
column3: but that was all. Later on
column4: Hello had a terrible crush on me
column5: but as I've already told you
column6: I never fell in love again.

column1: There's a saying: ""Time heals all wounds."" That's how it was with me. I told myself I'd forgotten Peter and no longer liked him in the least. But my memories of him were so strong that I had to admit to myself that the only reason I no longer liked him was that I was jealous of the other girls. This morning I realized that nothing has changed; on the contrary
column2: as I've grown older and more mature
column3: my love has grown along with me. I can understand now that Peter thought I was childish
column4: and yet it still hurts to think he'd forgotten me completely. I saw his face so clearly; I knew for certain that no one but Peter could have stuck in my mind that way.

column1: I've been in an utter state of confusion today. When Father kissed me this morning
column2: I wanted to shout
column3: ""Oh
column4: if only you were Peter!"" I've been thinking of him constantly
column5: and all day long I've been repeating to myself
column6: ""Oh
column7: Petel
column8: my darling
column9: darling Petel . . .""

column1: Where can I find help? I simply have to go on living and praying to God that
column2: if we ever get out of here
column3: Peter's path will cross mine and he'll gaze into my eyes
column4: read the love in them and say
column5: ""Oh
column6: Anne
column7: if I'd only known
column8: I'd have come to you long ago.""

column1: Once when Father and I were talking about sex
column2: he said I was too young to understand that kind of desire. But I thought I did understand it
column3: and now I'm sure I do. Nothing is as dear to me now as my darling Petel!

column1: I saw my face in the mirror
column2: and it looked so different. My eyes were clear and deep
column3: my cheeks were rosy
column4: which they hadn't been in weeks
column5: my mouth was much softer. I looked happy
column6: and yet there was something so sad in my expression that the smile immediately faded from my lips. I'm not happy
column7: since I know Petel's not thinking of me
column8: and yet I can still feel his beautiful eyes gazing at me and his cool
column9: soft cheek against mine. . . Oh
column10: Petel
column11: Petel
column12: how am I ever going to free myself from your image? Wouldn't anyone who took your place be a poor substitute? I love you
column13: with a love so great that it simply couldn't keep growing inside my heart
column14: but had to leap out and reveal itself in all its magnitude.

column1: A week ago
column2: even a day ago
column3: if you'd asked me
column4: ""Which of your friends do you think you'd be most likely to marry?"" I'd have answered
column5: ""Sally
column6: since he makes me feel good
column7: peaceful and safe!"" But now I'd cry
column8: ""Petel
column9: because I love him with all my heart and all my soul. I surrender myself completely!"" Except for that one thing: he may touch my face
column10: but that's as far as it goes. This morning I imagined I was in the front attic with Petel
column11: sitting on the floor by the windows
column12: and after talking for a while
column13: we both began to cry. Moments later I felt his mouth and his wonderful cheek! Oh
column14: Petel
column15: come to me. Think of me

column1: WEDNESDAY
column2: JANUARY 12
column3: 1944"|"The Diary of a Young Girl"|"Anne Frank"

column1: ap 04:00|"four o'clock"|"My dearest Kitty

There's no reason for me to go on describing all our quarrels and arguments down to the last detail. It's enough to tell you that we've divided many things like meat and fats and oils and are frying our own potatoes. Recently we've been eating a little extra rye bread because by four o'clock we're so hungry for dinner we can barely control our rumbling stomachs.
Mother's birthday is rapidly approaching. She received some extra sugar from Mr. Kugler
column2: which sparked off jealousy on the part of the van Daans
column3: because Mrs. van D. didn't receive any on her birthday. But what's the point of boring you with harsh words
column4: spiteful conversations and tears when you know they bore us even more?

column1: Mother has expressed a wish
column2: which isn't likely to come true any time soon: not to have to see Mr. van Daan's face for two whole weeks. I wonder if everyone who shares a house sooner or later ends up at odds with their fellow residents. Or have we just had a stroke of bad luck? At mealtime
column3: when Dussel helps himself to a quarter of the half-filled gravy boat and leaves the rest of us to do without
column4: I lose my appetite and feel like jumping to my feet
column5: knocking him off his chair and throwing him out the door.

column1: Are most people so stingy and selfish? I've gained some insight into human nature since I came here
column2: which is good
column3: but I've had enough for the present. Peter says the same.

column1: The war is going to go on despite our quarrels and our longing for freedom and fresh air
column2: so we should try to make the best of our stay here.

column1: I'm preaching
column2: but I also believe that if I live here much longer
column3: I'll turn into a dried-up old beanstalk. And all I really want is to be an honest-to-goodness teenager!

column1: Yours
column2: Anne

column1: WEDNESDAY EVENING
column2: JANUARY 19

column1: Dearest Kitty
I (there I go again!) don't know what's happened
column2: but since my dream I keep noticing how I've changed. By the way
column3: I dreamed about Peter again last night and once again I felt his eyes penetrate mine
column4: but this dream was less vivid and not quite as beautiful as the last.

column1: You know that I always used to be jealous of Margot's relationship with Father. There's not a trace of my jealousy left now; I still feel hurt when Father's nerves cause him to be unreasonable toward me
column2: but then I think
column3: ""I can't blame you for being the way you are. You talk so much about the minds of children and adolescents
column4: but you don't know the first thing about them!"" I long for more than Father's affection
column5: more than his hugs and kisses. Isn't it awful of me to be so preoccupied with myself? Shouldn't I
column6: who want to be good and kind
column7: forgive them first? I forgive Mother too
column8: but every time she makes a sarcastic remark or laughs at me
column9: it's all I can do to control myself.

column1: I know I'm far from being what I should; will I ever be?
Anne Frank
P.S. Father asked if I told you about the cake. For Mother's birthday
column2: she received a real mocha cake
column3: prewar quality
column4: from the office. It was a really nice day! But at the moment there's no room in my head for things like that. SATURDAY
column5: JANUARY 22

column1: ""I did my best

""Yes

column2: and he examined the pan of potatoes he was still holding. ""Oh

column4: he said
column5: and added
column6: as I took the pan from him

column4: but since he couldn't make a long complimentary speech
column5: he said everything with his eyes. I understood him so well and was very grateful. It still makes me happy to think back to those words and that look!

column3: this time for dinner

column6: he stood up

column1: I replied that it wasn't really necessary

column6: ""What are you working on?""

column1: ""French
column2: he replied.

column1: I asked if I could take a look at his lessons. Then I went to wash my hands and sat down across from him on the divan.
After I'd explained some French to him
column2: we began to talk. He told me that after the war he wanted to go to the Dutch East Indies and live on a rubber plantation. He talked about his life at home
column3: the black market and how he felt like a worthless bum. I told him he had a big inferiority complex. He talked about the war
column4: saying that Russia and England were bound to go to war against each other
column5: and about the Jews. He said life would have been much easier if he'd been a Christian or could become one after the war. I asked if he wanted to be baptized
column6: but that wasn't what he meant either. He said he'd never be able to feel like a Christian
column7: but that after the war he'd make sure nobody would know he was Jewish. I felt a momentary pang. It's such a shame he still has a touch of dishonesty in him.

column1: Peter added
column2: ""The Jews have been and always will be the chosen people!"" I answered
column3: ""Just this once
column4: I hope they'll be chosen for something good!"" But we went on chatting very pleasantly
column5: about Father
column6: about judging human character and all sorts of things
column7: so many that I can't even remember them all. I left at a quarter past five
column8: because Bep had arrived.

column1: That evening he said something else I thought was nice. We were talking about the picture of a movie star I'd once given him
column2: which has been hanging in his room for at least a year and a half. He liked it so much that I offered to give him a few more.

column1: ""No
column2: he replied
column3: ""I'd rather keep the one I've got. I look at it every day
column4: and the people in it have become my friends.""

column2: ""No
column3: I'm not afraid
column4: except when it comes to things about myself
column5: but I'm working on that.""

column1: Peter has a huge inferiority complex. For example

column3: he thanks me a thousand times. One of these days I'm going to say
column4: ""Oh
column5: cut it out! You're much better at English and geography!""

column2: we scrub
column3: sweep and do the laundry.

column2: then downstairs
column3: then up again and then to the bathroom
column4: where he devotes a whole hour to washing himself.

column1: Nine-thirty. The stoves are lit

column3: for Mr. Kugler's office when he saw that both the glass door and the office door were open. He was surprised

column2: he went downstairs to the front door
column3: checked the lock and found everything closed. ""Bep and

column1: Peter must just have been very careless this evening
column2: Mr. van. D. concluded. He remained for a while in Mr. Kugler's office
column3: switched off the lamp and went upstairs without worrying much about the open doors or the messy office. Early this morning Peter knocked at our door to tell us that the front door was wide open and that the projector and Mr. Kugler's new briefcase had disappeared from the closet. Peter was instructed to lock the door. Mr. van Daan told us his discoveries of the night before
column4: and we were extremely worried. The only explanation is that the burglar must have had a duplicate key

column8: fled with the loot after Mr. van Daan went upstairs and
column9: in his hurry
column10: not bothered to shut the door.

column1: Who could have our key? Why didn't the burglar go to the warehouse? Was it one of our own warehouse employees
column2: and will he turn us in
column3: now that he's heard Mr. van Daan and maybe even seen him?

column1: It's really scary

column1: Yours

When I looked into the candle tonight

column3: he gazes at me with such warmth in his eyes; I don't think it will take much for me to fall in love with him.

column2: because we turn white when it's cold and red when it's hot."" I said.

column2: rather
column3: question). ""Why not?"" he said
column4: and then it was time for dinner.

""Oh

column6: and I was in seventh heaven
column7: since I was sitting on Father's chair
column8: close to Peter.

column1: I went downstairs at quarter to eleven. When I went back up at eleven-thirty
column2: Peter was already waiting for me on the stairs. We talked until quarter to one. Whenever I leave the room
column3: for example after a meal
column4: and Peter has a chance and no one else can hear
column5: he says
column6: ""Bye
column7: Anne
column8: see you later.""

column1: Oh
column2: I'm so happy! I wonder if he's going to fall in love with me after all? In any case
column3: he's a nice boy
column4: and you have no idea how good it is to talk to him! Mrs. van D. thinks it's all right for me to talk to

column1: Peter
column2: but today she asked me teasingly
column3: ""Can I trust you two up there?"" ""Of course
column4: I protested. ""I take that as an insult!""

column1: Morning
column2: noon and night
column3: I look forward to seeing Peter.

column1: Yours
column2: Anne M. Frank

column1: PS. Before I forget
column2: last night everything was blanketed in snow. Now it's thawed and there's almost nothing left.

column1: MONDAY
column2: MARCH 6
column3: 1944"|"The Diary of a Young Girl"|"Anne Frank"

column1: ap 02:45|"quarter to three"|"Margot and I have been writing each other notes
column2: just for fun
column3: of course. Anne: It's strange
column4: but I can only remember the day after what has happened the night before. For example
column5: I suddenly remembered that Mr. Dussel was snoring loudly last night. (It's now quarter to three on Wednesday af- ternoon and Mr. Dussel is snoring again
column6: which is why it flashed through my mind
column7: of course.) When I had to use the potty
column8: I deliberately made more noise to get the snoring to stop.

column1: Margot: Which is better
column2: the snoring or the gasping for air?

column1: Anne: The snoring's better
column2: because it stops when I make noise
column3: without waking the person in question.

column1: What I didn't write to Margot
column2: but what I'll confess to you
column3: dear Kitty
column4: is that I've been dreaming of Peter a great deal. The night before last I dreamed I was skating right here in our living room with that little boy from the Apollo ice-skating rink; he was with his sister
column5: the girl with the spindly legs who always wore the same blue dress. I introduced myself
column6: overdoing it a bit
column7: and asked him his name. It was Peter. In my dream I wondered just how many Peters I actually knew!

column1: Then I dreamed we were standing in Peter's room
column2: facing each other beside the stairs. I said something to him; he gave me a kiss
column3: but replied that he didn't love me all that much and that I shouldn't flirt. In a desperate and pleading voice I said
column4: ""I'm not flirting
column5: Peter!""

column1: When I woke up
column2: I was glad Peter hasn't said it after all.

column1: Last night I dreamed we were kissing each other
column2: but

column1: Peter's cheeks were very disappointing: they weren't as soft as they looked. They were more like Father's cheeks-the cheeks of a man who already shaves. FRIDAY

The proverb ""Misfortunes never come singly"" defi- nitely applies to today. Peter just got through saying it. Let me tell you all the awful things that have happened and that are still hanging over our heads.
First
