column3: as a result of Henk and Aagje's wedding yesterday. She caught cold in the Westerkerk
column4: where the service was held. Second
column5: Mr. Kleiman hasn't returned to work since the last time his stomach started bleeding
column6: so Bep's been left to hold down the fort alone. Third
column7: the police have arrested a man (whose name I won't put in writing). It's terrible not only for him
column8: but for us as well
column9: since he's been supplying us with potatoes
column10: butter and jam. Mr. M.
column11: as I'll call him
column12: has five children under the age of thirteen
column13: and another on the way.

column1: Last night we had another little scare: we were in the middle of dinner when suddenly someone knocked on the wall next door. For the rest of the evening we were nervous and gloomy.
Lately I haven't been at all in the mood to write down what's been going on here. I've been more wrapped up in myself. Don't get me wrong
column2: I'm terribly upset about what's happened to poor
column3: good-hearted Mr. M.
column4: but there's not much room for him in my diary.

column1: Tuesday
column2: Wednesday and Thursday I was in Peter's room from four-thirty to five-fifteen. We worked on our French and chatted about one thing and another. I really look forward to that hour or so in the afternoon

column1: ap 04:00|four|"Dearest Kitty
Things are getting crazier here as the days go by.
Peter hasn't looked at me since yesterday. He's been acting as if he's mad at me. I'm doing my best not to chase after him and to talk to him as little as possible
column2: but it's not easy! What's going on
column3: what makes him keep me at arm's length one minute and rush back to my side the next? Perhaps I'm imagining that it's worse than it really is. Perhaps he's just moody like me
column4: and tomorrow everything will be all right again!

column1: I have the hardest time trying to maintain a normal facade when I'm feeling so wretched and sad. I have to talk
column2: help around the house
column3: sit with the others and
column4: above all
column5: act cheerful! Most of all I miss the outdoors and having a place where I can be alone for as long as I want! I think I'm getting everything all mixed up
column6: Kitty
column7: but then
column8: I'm in a state of utter confusion: on the one hand
column9: I'm half crazy with desire for him
column10: can hardly be in the same room without looking at him; and on the other hand
column11: I wonder why he should matter to me so much and why I can't be calm again!

column1: Day and night
column2: during every waking hour
column3: I do nothing but ask myself
column4: ""Have you given him enough chance to be alone? Have you been spending too much time upstairs? Do you talk too much about serious subjects he's not yet ready to talk about? Maybe he doesn't even like you? Has it all been your imagination? But then why has he told you so much about himself? Is he sorry he did?"" And a whole lot more.

column1: Yesterday afternoon I was so worn out by the sad news from the outside that I lay down on my divan for a nap. All I wanted was to sleep and not have to think. I slept until four
column2: but then I had to go next door. It wasn't easy
column3: answering all Mother's questions and inventing an excuse to explain my nap to Father. I pleaded a headache
column4: which wasn't a lie
column5: since I did have one. . . on the inside!

column1: Ordinary people
column2: ordinary girls
column3: teenagers like myself
column4: would think I'm a little nuts with all my self-pity. But that's just it. I pour my heart out to you
column5: and the rest of the time I'm as impudent
column6: cheerful and self-confident as possible to avoid questions and keep from getting on my own nerves. Margot is very kind and would like me to confide in her
column7: but I can't tell her everything. She takes me too seriously
column8: far too seriously
column9: and spends a lot of time thinking about her loony sister
column10: looking at me closely whenever I open my mouth and wondering
column11: ""Is she acting
column12: or does she really mean it?"" It's because we're always together. I don't want the person I confide in to be around me all the time. When will I untangle my jumbled thoughts? When will I find inner peace again?

column1: Yours
column2: Anne

column1: TUESDAY
column2: MARCH 14
column3: 1944"|"The Diary of a Young Girl"|"Anne Frank"

column1: ap 01:00|"one o'clock"|"Dearest Kitty
Whew! Released from the gloom and doom for a few moments! All I've been hearing today is: ""If this and that happens
column2: we're in trouble
column3: and if so-and-so gets sick
column4: we'll be left to fend for ourselves
column5: and if . . .""

column1: Well
column2: you know the rest
column3: or at any rate I assume you're famthar enough with the residents of the Annex to guess what they'd be talking about.

column1: The reason for all the ""ifs"" is that Mr. Kugler has been called up for a six-day work detail
column2: Bep is down with a bad cold and will probably have to stay home tomorrow
column3: Miep hasn't gotten over her flu
column4: and Mr. Kleiman's stom- ach bled so much he lost consciousness. What a tale of woe!

column1: We think Mr. Kugler should go directly to a reliable doctor for a medical certificate of ill health
column2: which he can present to the City Hall in Hilversum. The warehouse-employees have been given a day off tomorrow
column3: so Bep will be alone in the office. If (there's another ""if') Bep has to stay home
column4: the door will remain locked and we'll have to be as quiet as mice so the Keg Company won't hear us. At one o'clock Jan will come for half an hour to check on us poor forsaken souls
column5: like a zookeeper.

column1: This afternoon
column2: for the first time in ages
column3: Jan gave us some news of the outside world. You should have seen us gathered around him; it looked exactly like a print: ""At Grandmother's Knee.""

column1: He regaled his grateful audience with talk of-what else?-food. Mrs. P.
column2: a friend of Miep's
column3: has been cooking his meals. The day before yesterday Jan ate carrots with green peas
column4: yesterday he had the leftovers
column5: today she's cooking marrowfat peas
column6: and tomorrow she's plan- ning to mash the remaining carrots with potatoes.

column1: We asked about Miep's doctor.

""Doctor?"" said Jan. ""What doctor? I called him this morning and got his secretary on the line. I asked for a flu prescription and was told I could come pick it up tomor- row morning between eight and nine. If you've got a particularly bad case of flu
column2: the doctor himself comes to the phone and says
column3: 'Stick out your tongue and say ""Aah."" Oh
column4: I can hear it
column5: your throat's infected. I'll write out a prescription and you can bring it to the phar- macy. Good day.' And that's that. Easy job he's got
column6: diagnosis by phone. But I shouldn't blame the doctors."" After all
column7: a person has only two hands
column8: and these days there're too many patients and too few doctors.""

column1: Still
column2: we all had a good laugh at Jan's phone call. I can just imagine what a doctor's waiting room looks like these days. Doctors no longer turn up their noses at the poorer patients
column3: but at those with minor illnesses. ""Hey
column4: what are you doing here?"" they think. ""Go to the end of the line; real patients have priority!""

column1: Yours
column2: Anne

column1: THURSDAY
column2: MARCH 16
column3: 1944"|"The Diary of a Young Girl"|"Anne Frank"

column1: ap 08:15|eight-fifteen|"My dearest darling
Everything turned out all right after all; Bep just had a sore throat
column2: not the flu
column3: and Mr. Kugler got a medical certificate to excuse him from the work detail. The entire Annex breathed a huge sigh of relief. Everything's fine here! Except that Margot and I are rather tired of our parents.

column1: Don't get me wrong. I still love Father as much as ever and Margot loves both Father and Mother
column2: but when you're as old as we are
column3: you want to make a few decisions for yourself
column4: get out from under their thumb. Whenever I go upstairs
column5: they ask what I'm going to do
column6: they won't let me salt my food
column7: Mother asks me every evening at eight-fifteen if it isn't time for me to change into my nighty
column8: I and they have to approve every book I read. I must admit
column9: they're not at all strict about that and let me read nearly everything
column10: but Margot and I are sick and tired of having to listen to their comments and questions all day long.

column1: There's something else that displeases them: I no longer feel like giving them little kisses morning
column2: noon and night. All those cute nicknames seem so affected
column3: and Father's fondness for talking about farting and going to the bathroom is disgusting. In short
column4: I'd like nothing better than to do without their company for a while
column5: and they don't understand that. Not that Margot and I have ever said any of this to them. What would be the point? They wouldn't understand anyway.

column1: Margot said last night
column2: ""What really bothers me is that if you happen to put your head in your hands and sigh once or twice
column3: they immediately ask whether you have a headache or don't feel well.""

column1: For both of us
column2: it's been quite a blow to suddenly realize that very little remains of the close and harmoni- ous family we used to have at home! This is mostly because everything's out of kilter here. By that I mean that we're treated like children when it comes to external matters
column3: while
column4: inwardly
column5: we're much older than other girls our age. Even though I'm only fourteen
column6: I know what I want
column7: I know who's right and who's wrong
column8: I have my own opinions
column9: ideas and principles
column10: and though it may sound odd coming from a teenager
column11: I feel I'm more of a person than a child-I feel I'm completely independent of others. I know I'm better at debating or carrying on a discussion than Mother
column12: I know I'm more objective
column13: I don't exaggerate as much
column14: I'm much tidier and better with my hands
column15: and because of that I feel (this may make you laugh) that I'm superior to her in many ways. To love someone
column16: I have to admire and respect the person
column17: but I feel neither respect nor admiration for Mother!

column1: Everything would be all right if only I had Peter
column2: since I admire him in many ways. He's so decent and clever!

column1: Yours
column2: Anne M. Frank

column1: ap 05:00|five|"Dearest Kitty
Yesterday was a very important day for me. After lunch everything was as usual. At five I put on the potatoes
column2: and Mother gave me some blood sausage to take to Peter. I didn't want to at first
column3: but I finally went. He wouldn't accept the sausage
column4: and I had the dreadful feel- ing it was still because of that argument we'd had about distrust. Suddenly I couldn't bear it a moment longer and my eyes filled with tears. Without another word
column5: I re- turned the platter to Mother and went to the bathroom to have a good cry. Afterward I decided to talk things out with Peter. Before dinner the four of us were helping him with a crossword puzzle
column6: so I couldn't say anything. But as we were sitting down to eat
column7: I whispered to him
column8: ""Are you going to practice your shorthand tonight
column9: Peter?""

column1: ""No
column2: was his reply.

column1: ""I'd like to talk to you later on.""
He agreed.
After the dishes were done
column2: I went to his room and asked if he'd refused the sausage because of our last quar- rel. Luckily
column3: that wasn't the reason; he just thought it was bad manners to seem so eager. It had been very hot downstairs and my face was as red as a lobster. So after taking down some water for Margot
column4: I went back up to get a little fresh air. For the sake of appearances
column5: I first went and stood beside the van Daans' window before going to Peter's room. He was standing on the left side of the open window
column6: so I went over to the right side. It's much easier to talk next to an open window in semidarkness than in broad daylight
column7: and I think Peter felt the same way. We told each other so much
column8: so very much
column9: that I can't repeat it all. But it felt good; it was the most won- derful evening I've ever had in the Annex. I'll give you a brief description of the various subjects we touched on.

column1: First we talked about the quarrels and how I see them in a very different light these days
column2: and then about how we've become alienated from our parents. I told Peter about Mother and Father and Margot and myself. At one point he asked
column3: ""You always give each other a good-night kiss
column4: don't you?""

column1: ""One? Dozens of them. You don't
column2: do you?""

column1: ""No
column2: I've never really kissed anyone.""

column1: ""Not even on your birthday?""
""Yeah
column2: on my birthday I have.""

column1: We talked about how neither of us really trusts our parents
column2: and how his parents love each other a great deal and wish he'd confide in them
column3: but that he doesn't want to. How I cry my heart out in bed and he goes up to the loft and swears. How Margot and I have only recently gotten to know each other and yet still tell each other very little
column4: since we're always together. We talked about every imaginable thing
column5: about trust
column6: feelings and ourselves. Oh
column7: Kitty
column8: he was just as I thought he would be.

column1: Then we talked about the year 1942
column2: and how different we were back then; we don't even recognize ourselves from that period. How we couldn't stand each other at first. He'd thought I was a noisy pest
column3: and I'd quickly concluded that he was nothing special. I didn't understand why he didn't flirt with me
column4: but now I'm glad. He also mentioned how he often used to retreat to his room. I said that my noise and exuberance and his silence were two sides of the same coin
column5: and that I also liked peace and quiet but don't have anything for myself alone
column6: except my diary
column7: and that everyone would rather see the back of me
column8: starting with Mr. Dussel
column9: and that I don't always want to sit with my parents. We discussed how glad he is that my parents have children and how glad I am that he's here.

column1: How I now understand his need to withdraw and his relationship to his parents
column2: and how much I'd like to help him when they argue.

column1: ""But you're always a help to me!"" he said.
""How?"" I asked
column2: greatly surprised.

column1: ""By being cheerful.""
That was the nicest thing he said all evening. He also told me that he didn't mind my coming to his room the way he used to; in fact
column2: he liked it. I also told him that all of Father's and Mother's pet names were meaningless
column3: that a kiss here and there didn't automatically lead to trust. We also talked about doing things your own way
column4: the diary
column5: loneliness
column6: the difference between everyone's inner and outer selves
column7: my mask
column8: etc.

column1: It was wonderful. He must have come to love me as a friend
column2: and
column3: for the time being
column4: that's enough. I'm so grateful and happy
column5: I can't find the words. I must apolo- gize
column6: Kitty
column7: since my style is not up to my usual standard today. I've just written whatever came into my head!

column1: I have the feeling that Peter and I share a secret. Whenever he looks at me with those eyes
column2: with that smile and that wink
column3: it's as if a light goes on inside me. I hope things will stay like this and that we'll have many
column4: many more happy hours together.

column1: Your grateful and happy Anne
MONDAY
column2: MARCH 20
column3: 1944"|"The Diary of a Young Girl"|"Anne Frank"

column1: ap 10:15|ten-fifteen|"Dearest Kitty
I received this letter last night from Margot:
Dear Anne
After your letter of yesterday I have the unpleasant feeling that your conscience bothers you whenever you go to Peter's to work or talk; there's really no reason for that. In my heart
column2: I know there's someone who deserves t my trust (as I do his)
column3: and I wouldn't be able to tolerate Peter in his place. However
column4: as you wrote
column5: I do think of Peter as a kind of brother. . . a younger brother; we've been sending out feelers
column6: and a brotherly and sisterly affection mayor may not develop at some later date
column7: but it's certainly not reached that stage yet. So there's no need for you to feel sorry for me. Now that you've found companionship
column8: enjoy it as much as you can.

column1: In the meantime
column2: things are getting more and more wonderful here. I think
column3: Kitty
column4: that true love may be developing in the Annex. All those jokes about marrying Peter if we stayed here long enough weren't so silly after all. Not that I'm thinking of marrying him
column5: mind you. I don't even know what he'll be like when he grows up. Or if we'll even love each other enough to get married. I'm sure now that Peter loves me too; I just don't know in what way. I can't figure out if he wants only a good friend
column6: or if he's attracted to me as a girl or as a sister. When he said I always helped him when his parents were arguing
column7: I was tremendously happy; it was one step toward making me believe in his friendship. I asked him yesterday what he'd do if there were a dozen Annes who kept popping in to see him. His answer was: ""If they were all like you
column8: it wouldn't be so bad."" He's extremely hospitable
column9: and I think he really likes to see me. Mean- while
column10: he's been working hard at learning French
column11: even studying in bed until ten-fifteen.

column1: Oh
column2: when I think back to Saturday night
column3: to our words
column4: our voices
column5: I feel satisfied with myself for the very first time; what I mean is
column6: I'd still say the same and wouldn't want to change a thing
column7: the way I usually do. He's so handsome
column8: whether he's smthng or just sitting still. He's so sweet and good and beautiful. I think what surprised him most about me was when he discovered that I'm not at all the superficial
column9: worldly Anne I appear to be
column10: but a dreamer
column11: like he is
column12: with just as many troubles!

column1: Last night after the dinner dishes
column2: I waited for him to ask me to stay upstairs. But nothing happened; I went away. He came downstairs to tell Dussel it was time to listen to the radio and hung around the bathroom for a while
column3: but when Dussel took too long
column4: he went back upstairs. He paced up and down his room and went to bed early.

column1: The entire evening I was so restless I kept going to the bathroom to splash cold water on my face. I read a bit
column2: daydreamed some more
column3: looked at the clock and waited
column4: waited
column5: waited
column6: all the while listening to his foot- steps. I went to bed early
column7: exhausted.

column1: Tonight I have to take a bath
column2: and tomorrow?

column1: Tomorrow's so far away!
Yours
column2: Anne M. Frank

column1: My answer:
Dearest Margot

I think the best thing is simply to wait and see what happens. It can't be much longer before Peter and I will have to decide whether to go back to the way we were or do some- thing else. I don't know how it'll turn out; I can't see any farther than the end of my nose.
But I'm certain of one thing: if Peter and I do become friends
column2: I'm going to tell him you're also very fond of him and are prepared to help him if he needs you. You wouldn't want me to
column3: I'm sure
column4: but I don't care; I don't know what Peter thinks of you
column5: but I'll ask him when the time comes. It's certainly nothing bad-on the contrary! You're welcome to join us in the attic
column6: or wherever we are. You won't be disturbing us
column7: because we have an unspoken agreement to talk only in the evenings when it's dark.

column1: Keep your spirits up! I'm doing my best
column2: though it's not always easy. Your time may come sooner than you think.

Mr. Bolkestein

column5: everyone pounced on my diary. Just imagine how interesting it would be if I were to publish a novel about the Secret Annex. The title alone would make people think it was a detective story. Seriously
column6: though
column7: ten years after the war people would find it very amusing to read how we lived
column8: what we ate and what we talked about as Jews in hiding. Although I tell you a great deal about our lives
column9: you still know very little about us. How frightened the women are during air raids; last Sunday
column10: for instance
column11: when 350 British planes dropped 550 tons of bombs on IJmuiden
column12: so that the houses trembled like blades of grass in the wind. Or how many epidemics are raging here.

column1: You know nothing of these matters
column2: and it would take me all day to describe everything down to the last detail. People have to stand in line to buy vegetables and all kinds of goods; doctors can't visit their patients
column3: since their cars and bikes are stolen the moment they turn their backs; burglaries and thefts are so common that you ask yourself what's suddenly gotten into the Dutch to make them so light-fingered. Little children
column4: eight- and elevenyear-olds
column5: smash the windows of people's homes and steal whatever they can lay their hands on. People don't dare leave the house for even five minutes
column6: since they're liable to come back and find all their belongings gone. Every day the newspapers are filled with reward notices for the return of stolen typewriters
column7: Persian rugs
column8: electric clocks
column9: fabrics
column10: etc. The electric clocks on street corners are dismantled
column11: public phones are stripped down to the last wire. Morale among the Dutch can't be good. Everyone's hungry; except for the ersatz coffee
column12: a week's food ration doesn't last two days. The invasion's long in coming
column13: the men are being shipped off to Germany
column14: the children are sick or undernourished
column15: everyone's wearing worn-out clothes and run-down shoes. A new sole costs 7.50 guil- ders on the black market. Besides
column17: or if they do
column18: you have to wait four months for your shoes
column19: which might very well have disappeared in the meantime.

column3: the police
column4: the officials-they're all either helping their fellow citizens or denouncing them and sending them off to prison. Fortunately
column5: only a small percentage of Dutch people are on the wrong side.

column1: This incident has brought about a whole lot of changes. As of now
column2: Dussel will be doing his work in the bathroom
column3: and Peter will be patrolling the house between eight-thirty and nine-thirty. Peter isn't allowed to open his window anymore

column5: and tonight a carpenter from the underground is coming to make a barricade out of our white Frankfurt bedsteads. Debates are going on left and right in the Annex. Mr. Kugler has reproached us for our carelessness. Jan also said we should never go downstairs. What we have to do now is find out whether Sleegers can be trusted

column7: how to make the barricade
column8: all sorts of things.

column1: We've been strongly reminded of the fact that we're Jews in chains
column2: chained to one spot
column3: without any rights
column4: but with a thousand obligations. We must put our feelings aside; we must be brave and strong
column5: bear discomfort with- out complaint
column6: do whatever is in our power and trust in God. One day this terrible war will be over. The time will come when we'll be people again and not just Jews!

column1: Who has inflicted this on us? Who has set us apart from all the rest? Who has put us through such suffering? It's God who has made us the way we are

column3: we're doomed
column4: but if
column5: after all this suffering
column6: there are still Jews left
column7: the Jewish people will be held up as an example. Who knows
column8: maybe our religion will teach the world and all the people in it about goodness
column9: and that's the reason
column10: the only reason
column11: we have to suffer. We can never be just Dutch
column12: or just English
column13: or whatever
column14: we will always be Jews as well. And we'll have to keep on being Jews

column1: Be brave! Let's remember our duty and perform it without complaint. There will be a way out. God has never deserted our people. Through the ages Jews have had to suffer
column2: but through the ages they've gone on living
column3: and the centuries of suffering have only made them stronger. The weak shall fall and the strong shall survive and not be defeated!

column1: That night I really thought I was going to die. I waited for the police and I was ready for death
column2: like a soldier on a battlefield. I'd gladly have given my life for my country. But now
column3: now that I've been spared
column4: my first wish after the war is to become a Dutch citizen. I love the Dutch
column5: I love this country
column6: I love the language
column7: and I want to work here. And even if I have to write to the Queen herself
column8: I won't give up until I've reached my goal!

column1: I'm becoming more and more independent of my parents. Young as I am
column2: I face life with more courage and have a better and truer sense of justice than Mother. I know what I want
column3: I have a goal
column4: I have opinions
column5: a religion and love. If only I can be myself
column6: I'll be satisfied. I know that I'm a woman
column7: a woman with inner strength and a great deal of courage!

column1: If God lets me live
column2: I'll achieve more than Mother ever did
column3: I'll make my voice heard
column4: I'll go out into the world and work for mankind!

column1: I now know that courage and happiness are needed first!
Yours

column3: five-thirty. I went and sat with Peter by his window and listened
column4: so close we could feel each other's bodies trembling; we spoke a word or two from time to time and listened intently. Next door they took down the blackout screen. They made a list of everything they were planning to tell Mr. Kleiman over the phone
column5: because they intended to call him at seven and ask him to send someone over. They were taking a big chance
column6: since the police guard at the door or in the warehouse might hear them calling
column7: but there was an even greater risk that the police would return.

column1: I'm enclosing their list
column2: but for the sake of clarity
column3: I'll copy it here. Buralary: Police in building
column4: up to bookcase
column5: but no farther. Burglars apparently interrupted
column6: forced warehouse door
column7: fled through garden. Main entrance bolted; Kugler must have left through second door.

column1: Typewriter and adding machine safe in black chest in private office. Miep's or Bep's laundry in washtub in kitchen.
Only Bep or Kugler have key to second door; lock may be broken.
Try to warn jan and get key
column2: look around office; also feed cat.

column1: For the rest
column2: everything went according to plan. Mr. Kleiman was phoned
column3: the poles were removed from the doors
column4: the typewriter was put back in the chest. Then we all sat around the table again and waited for either jan or the police. Peter had dropped off to sleep and Mr. van Daan ANNE FRANK and I were lying on the floor when we heard loud footsteps below. I got up quietly. ""It's Jan!"" ""No
column5: no
column6: it's the police!"" they all said.

column1: There was a knocking at our bookcase. Miep whis- tled. This was too much for Mrs. van Daan
column2: who sank limply in her chair
column3: white as a sheet. If the tension had lasted another minute
column4: she would have fainted.

column1: Jan and Miep came in and were met with a delightful scene. The table alone would have been worth a photograph: a copy of Cinema &.. Theater
column2: opened to a page of dancing girls and smeared with jam and pectin
column3: which we'd been taking to combat the diarrhea
column4: two jam jars
column5: half a bread roll
column6: a quarter of a bread roll
column7: pectin
column8: a mirror
column9: a comb
column10: matches
column11: ashes
column12: cigarettes
column13: tobacco
column14: an ashtray
column17: a flashlight
column19: toilet paper

column1: Jan and Miep were of course greeted with shouts and tears. Jan nailed a pinewood board over the gap in the door and went off again with Miep to inform the police of the break-in. Miep had also found a note under the ware- house door from Sleegers
column2: the night watchman
column3: who had noticed the hole and alerted the police. Jan was also planning to see Sleegers.

column1: So we had half an hour in which to put the house and ourselves to rights. I've never seen such a transformation as in those thirty minutes. Margot and I got the beds ready downstairs
column2: went to the bathroom
column3: brushed our teeth
column4: washed our hands and combed our hair. Then I straightened up the room a bit and went back upstairs. The table had already been cleared
column5: so we got some water
column6: made coffee and tea
column7: boiled the milk and set the table. Father and Peter emptied our improvised potties and rinsed them with warm water and powdered bleach. The largest one was filled to the brim and was so heavy they had a hard time lifting it. To make things worse
column8: it was leaking
column9: so they had to put it in a bucket.

column1: At eleven o'clock Jan was back and joined us at the table
column2: and gradually everyone began to relax. Jan had the following story to tell:

column1: Mr. Sleegers was asleep
column2: but his wife told Jan that her husband had discovered the hole in the door while making his rounds. He called in a policeman
column3: and the two of them searched the building. Mr. Sleegers
column4: in his capacity as night watchman
column5: patrols the area every night on his bike
column6: accompanied by his two dogs. His wife said he would come on Tuesday and tell Mr. Kugler the rest. No one at the police station seemed to know anything about the break-in
column7: but they made a note to come first thing Tuesday morning to have a look.

column1: On the way back Jan happened to run into Mr. van Hoeven
column2: the man who supplies us with potatoes
column3: and told him of the break-in. ""I know
column4: Mr. van Hoeven calmly replied. ""Last night when my wife and I were walking past your building
column5: I saw a gap in the door. My wife wanted to walk on
column6: but I peeked inside with a flashlight
column7: and that's when the burglars must have run off. To be on the safe side
column8: I didn't call the police. I thought it wouldn't be wise in your case. I don't know anything
column9: but I have my suspicions."" Jan thanked him and went on. Mr. van Hoeven obviously suspects we're here
column10: because he always delivers the potatoes at lunchtime. A decent man!

column1: It was one o'clock by the time Jan left and we'd done the dishes. All eight of us went to bed. I woke up at quarter to three and saw that Mr. Dussel was already up. My face rumpled with sleep
column2: I happened to run into Peter in the bathroom
column3: just after he'd come downstairs. We agreed to meet in the office. I freshened up a bit and went down.

column1: ""After all this
column2: do you still dare go to the front attic?"" he asked. I nodded
column3: grabbed my pillow
column4: with a cloth wrapped around it
column5: and we went up together. The weather was gorgeous
column6: and even though the air-raid sirens soon began to wail
column7: we stayed where we were. Peter put his arm around my shoulder
column8: I put mine around his
column9: and we sat quietly like this until four o'clock
column10: when Margot came to get us for coffee.

column1: We ate our bread
column2: drank our lemonade and joked (we were finally able to again)
column3: and for the rest everything was back to normal. That evening I thanked Peter because he'd been the bravest of us all.

column1: None of us have ever been in such danger as we were that night. God was truly watching over us. Just think-the police were right at the bookcase
column2: the light was on
column3: and still no one had discovered our hiding place! ""Now we're done for!"" I'd whispered at that moment
column4: but once again we were spared. When the invasion comes and the bombs start falling
column5: it'll be every man for himself
column6: but this time we feared for those good
column7: innocent Christians who are helping us. ""We've been saved
column8: keep on saving us!"" That's all we can say.

column1: This incident has brought about a whole lot of changes. As of now
column2: Dussel will be doing his work in the bathroom
column3: and Peter will be patrolling the house between eight-thirty and nine-thirty. Peter isn't allowed to open his window anymore
column4: since one of the Keg people noticed it was open. We can no longer flush the toilet after nine-thirty at night. Mr. Sleegers has been hired as night watchman
column5: and tonight a carpenter from the underground is coming to make a barricade out of our white Frankfurt bedsteads. Debates are going on left and right in the Annex. Mr. Kugler has reproached us for our carelessness. Jan also said we should never go downstairs. What we have to do now is find out whether Sleegers can be trusted
column6: whether the dogs will bark if they hear someone behind the door
column7: how to make the barricade
column8: all sorts of things.

column1: We've been strongly reminded of the fact that we're Jews in chains
column2: chained to one spot
column3: without any rights
column4: but with a thousand obligations. We must put our feelings aside; we must be brave and strong
column5: bear discomfort with- out complaint
column6: do whatever is in our power and trust in God. One day this terrible war will be over. The time will come when we'll be people again and not just Jews!

column1: Who has inflicted this on us? Who has set us apart from all the rest? Who has put us through such suffering? It's God who has made us the way we are
column2: but it's also God who will lift us up again. In the eyes of the world
column3: we're doomed
column4: but if
column5: after all this suffering
column6: there are still Jews left
column7: the Jewish people will be held up as an example. Who knows
column8: maybe our religion will teach the world and all the people in it about goodness
column9: and that's the reason
column10: the only reason
column11: we have to suffer. We can never be just Dutch
column12: or just English
column13: or whatever
column14: we will always be Jews as well. And we'll have to keep on being Jews

column1: Be brave! Let's remember our duty and perform it without complaint. There will be a way out. God has never deserted our people. Through the ages Jews have had to suffer
column2: but through the ages they've gone on living
column3: and the centuries of suffering have only made them stronger. The weak shall fall and the strong shall survive and not be defeated!

column1: That night I really thought I was going to die. I waited for the police and I was ready for death
column2: like a soldier on a battlefield. I'd gladly have given my life for my country. But now
column3: now that I've been spared
column4: my first wish after the war is to become a Dutch citizen. I love the Dutch
column5: I love this country
column6: I love the language
column7: and I want to work here. And even if I have to write to the Queen herself
column8: I won't give up until I've reached my goal!

column1: I'm becoming more and more independent of my parents. Young as I am
column2: I face life with more courage and have a better and truer sense of justice than Mother. I know what I want
column3: I have a goal
column4: I have opinions
column5: a religion and love. If only I can be myself
column6: I'll be satisfied. I know that I'm a woman
column7: a woman with inner strength and a great deal of courage!

column1: If God lets me live
column2: I'll achieve more than Mother ever did
column3: I'll make my voice heard
column4: I'll go out into the world and work for mankind!

column1: I now know that courage and happiness are needed first!
Yours
column2: Anne M. Frank

Remember yesterday's date
column2: since it was a red-letter day for me. Isn't it an important day for every girl when she gets her first kiss? Well then
column3: it's no less important to me. The time Bram kissed me on my right cheek or Mr. Woudstra on my right hand doesn't count. How did I suddenly come by this kiss? I'll tell you.

column1: Last night at eight I was sitting with Peter on his divan and it wasn't long before he put an arm around me. (Since it was Saturday
column2: he wasn't wearing his overalls.)""Why don t we move over a little
column3: I said
column4: ""so won t keep bumping my head against the cupboard.""

column1: He moved so far over he was practically in the corner. I slipped my arm under his and across his back
column2: and he put his arm around my shoulder
column3: so that I was nearly engulfed by him. We've sat like this on other occasions
column4: but never so close as we were last night. He held me firmly against him
column5: my left side against his chest; my heart had already begun to beat faster
column6: but there was more to come. He wasn't satisfied until my head lay on his shoulder
column7: with his on top of mine. I sat up again after about five minutes
column8: but before long he took my head in his hands and put it back next to his. Oh
column9: it was so wonderful. I could hardly talk
column10: my pleasure was too intense; he caressed my cheek and arm
column11: a bit clumsily
column12: and played with my hair. Most of the time our heads were touching.

column1: I can't tell you
column2: Kitty
column3: the feeling that ran through me. I was too happy for words
column4: and I think he was too.

column1: At nine-thirty we stood up. Peter put on his tennis shoes so he wouldn't make much noise on his nightly round of the building
column2: and I was standing next to him. How I suddenly made the right movement
column3: I don't know
column4: but before we went downstairs
column5: he gave me a. kiss
column6: through my hair
column7: half on my left cheek and half on my ear. I tore downstairs without looking back
column8: and I long so much for today.

column1: ap 07:00|"seven o'clock"|"Dearest Kitty
Do you think Father and Mother would approve of a girl my age sitting on a divan and kissing a seventeen-and- a-half-year-old boy? I doubt they would
column2: but I have to trust my own judgment in this matter. It's so peaceful and safe
column3: lying in his arms and dreaming
column4: it's so thrilling to feel his cheek against mine
column5: it's so wonderful to know there's someone waiting for me. But
column6: and there is a but
column7: will Peter want to leave it at that? I haven't forgotten his promise
column8: but. . . he is a boy!

column1: I know I'm starting at a very young age. Not even fifteen and already so independent-that's a little hard for other people to understand. I'm pretty sure Margot would never kiss a boy unless there was some talk of an engagement or marriage. Neither Peter nor I has any such plans. I'm also sure that Mother never touched a man before she met Father. What would my girlfriends or Jacque say if they knew I'd lain in Peter's arms with my heart against his chest
column2: my head on his shoulder and his head and face against mine!

column1: Oh
column2: Anne
column3: how terribly shocking! But seriously
column4: I don't think it's at all shocking; we're cooped up here
column5: cut off from the world
column6: anxious and fearful
column7: especially lately. Why should we stay apart when we love each other? Why shouldn't we kiss each other in times like these? Why should we wait until we've reached a suitable age? Why should we ask anybody's permission? I've decided to look out for my own interests. He'd never want to hurt me or make me unhappy. Why shouldn't I do what my heart tells me and makes both of us happy?

column1: Yet I have a feeling
column2: Kitty
column3: that you can sense my doubt. It must be my honesty rising in revolt against all this sneaking around. Do you think it's my duty to tell Father what I'm up to? Do you think our secret should be shared with a third person? Much of the beauty would be lost
column4: but would it make me feel better inside? I'll bring it up with him.

column1: Oh
column2: yes
column3: I still have so much I want to discuss with him
column4: since I don't see the point of just cuddling. Sharing our thoughts with each other requires a great deal of trust
column5: but we'll both be stronger because of it!

column1: Yours
column2: Anne M. Frank

column1: P.S. We were up at six yesterday morning
column2: because the whole family heard the sounds of a break-in again. It must have been one of our neighbors who was the victim this time. When we checked at seven o'clock
column3: our doors were still shut tight
column4: thank goodness!

For the last ten days Dussel hasn't been on speaking terms with Mr. van Daan
column2: and all because of the new security measures since the break-in. One of these was that he's no longer allowed to go downstairs in the evenings. Peter and Mr. van Daan make the last round every night at nine-thirty
column3: and after that no one may go downstairs. We can't flush the toilet anymore after eight at night or after eight in the morning. The windows may be opened only in the morning when the lights go on in Mr. Kugler's office
column4: and they can no longer be propped open with a stick at night. This last measure is the reason for Dussel's sulking. He claims that Mr. van Daan bawled him out
column5: but he has only himself to blame. He says he'd rather live without food than without air
column6: and that they simply must figure out a way to keep the windows open.

column1: ""I'll have to speak to Mr. Kugler about this

column1: ""Everything's always happening behind my back. I'll have to talk to your father about that.""
He's also not allowed to sit in Mr. Kugler's office anymore on Saturday afternoons or Sundays
column2: because the manager of Keg's might hear him if he happens to be next door. Dussel promptly went and sat there anyway. Mr. van Daan was furious
column3: and Father went downstairs to talk to Dussel
column4: who came up with some flimsy excuse
column5: but even Father didn't fall for it this time. Now Father's keep- ing his dealings with Dussel to a minimum because Dussel insulted him. Not one of us knows what he said

column3: but only God can help him now!

column1: I've written an amusing story called ""Blurry the Explorer

At the moment I'm reading Emperor Charles V

column1: ap 08:30|eight-thirty|"Dearest Kitty
I've never forgotten my dream of Peter Schiff (see the beginning of January). Even now I can still feel his cheek against mine
column2: and that wonderful glow that made up for all the rest. Once in a while I'd had the same feeling with this Peter
column3: but never so intensely. . . until last night. We were sitting on the divan
column4: as usual
column5: in each other's arms. Suddenly the everyday Anne slipped away and the second Anne took her place. The second Anne
column6: who's never overconfident or amusing
column7: but wants only to love and be gentle.

column1: I sat pressed against him and felt a wave of emotion come over me. Tears rushed to my eyes; those from the left fell on his overalls
column2: while those from the right trickled down my nose and into the air and landed beside the first. Did he notice? He made no movement to show that he had. Did he feel the same way I did? He hardly said a word. Did he realize he had two Annes at his side? My questions went unanswered.

column1: At eight-thirty I stood up and went to the window
column2: where we always say good-bye. I was still trembling
column3: I was still Anne number two. He came over to me
column4: and I threw my arms around his neck and kissed him on his left cheek. I was about to kiss the other cheek when my mouth met his
column5: and we pressed our lips together. In a daze
column6: we embraced
column7: over and over again
column8: never to stop
column9: oh! Peter needs tenderness. For the first time in his life he's discovered a girl; for the first time he's seen that even the biggest pests also have an inner self and a heart
column10: and are transformed as soon as they're alone with you. For the first time in his life he's given himself and his friendship to another person. He's never had a friend before
column11: boy or girl. Now we've found each other. I
column12: for that matter
column13: didn't know him either
column14: had never had someone I could confide in

column1: The same question keeps nagging me: ""Is it right?"" Is it right for me to yield so soon
column2: for me to be so passionate
column3: to be filled with as much passion and desire as Peter? Can I
column4: a girl
column5: allow myself to go that far?

column1: There's only one possible answer: ""I'm longing so much. . . and have for such a long time. I'm so lonely and now I've found comfort!""
In the mornings we act normally
column2: in the afternoons too
column3: except now and then. But in the evenings the suppressed longing of the entire day
column4: the happiness and the bliss of all the times before come rushing to the surface
column5: and all we can think about is each other. Every night
column6: after our last kiss
column7: I feel like running away and never looking him in the eyes again. Away
column8: far away into the darkness and alone!

column1: And what awaits me at the bottom of those fourteen stairs? Bright lights
column2: questions and laughter. I have to act normally and hope they don't notice anything.

column1: My heart is still too tender to be able to recover so quickly from a shock like the one I had last night. The gentle Anne makes infrequent appearances
column2: and she's not about to let herself be shoved out the door so soon after she's arrived. Peter's reached a part of me that no one has ever reached before
column3: except in my dream! He's taken hold of me and turned me inside out. Doesn't everyone need a little quiet time to put themselves to rights again? Oh
column4: Peter
column5: what have you done to me? What do you want from me?

column1: Where will this lead? Oh
column2: now I understand Bep. Now
column3: now that I'm going through it myself
column4: I understand her doubts; if I were older and he wanted to marry me
column5: what would my answer be? Anne
column6: be honest! You wouldn't be able to marry him. But it's so hard to let go. Peter still has too little character
column7: too little willpower
column8: too little courage and strength. He's still a child
column9: emotionally no older than I am; all he wants is happiness and peace of mind. Am I really only fourteen? Am I really just a silly schoolgirl? Am I really so inexperienced in everything? I have more experience than most; I've experienced something almost no one my age ever has.

column1: I'm afraid of myself
column2: afraid my longing is making me yield too soon. How can it ever go right with other boys later on? Oh
column3: it's so hard
column4: the eternal struggle between heart and mind. There's a time and a place for both
column5: but how can I be sure that I've chosen the right time?

column1: Yours
column2: Anne M. Frank

column1: ap 11:30|eleven-thirty|"Dearest Kitty
First the weekly news! We're having a vacation from politics. There's nothing
column2: and I mean absolutely nothing
column3: to report. I'm also gradually starting to believe that the invasion will come. After all
column4: they can't let the Russians do all the dirty work; actually
column5: the Russians aren't doing anything at the moment either.

column1: Mr. Kleiman comes to the office every morning now. He got a new set of springs for Peter's divan
column2: so Peter will have to get to work reupholstering it; Not surprisingly
column3: he isn't at all in the mood. Mr. Kleiman also brought some flea powder for the cats.

column1: Have I told you that our Boche has disappeared? We haven't seen hide nor hair of her since last Thursday. She's probably already in cat heaven
column2: while some animal lover has turned her into a tasty dish. Perhaps some girl who can afford it will be wearing a cap made of Boche's fur. Peter is heartbroken. For the last two weeks we've been eating lunch at eleven-thirty on Saturdays; in the mornings we have to make do with a cup of hot cereal. Starting tomorrow it'll be like this every day; that saves us a meal. Vegetables are still very hard to come by. This afternoon we had rotten boiled lettuce. Ordinary lettuce
column3: spinach and boiled let- tuce
column4: that's all there is. Add to that rotten potatoes
column5: and you have a meal fit for a king!

column1: I hadn't had my period for more than two months
column2: but it finally started last Sunday. Despite the mess and bother
column3: I'm glad it hasn't deserted me. As you can no doubt imagine
column4: we often say in despair
column5: ""What's the point of the war? Why
column6: oh
column7: why can't people live together peacefully? Why all this destruction?""

column1: The question is understandable
column2: but up to now no one has come up with a satisfactory answer. Why is England manufacturing bigger and better airplanes and bombs and at the same time churning out new houses for reconstruction? Why are millions spent on the war each day
column3: while not a penny is available for medical science
column4: artists or the poor? Why do people have to starve when mountains of food are rotting away in other parts of the world? Oh
column5: why are people so crazy?

column1: I don't believe the war is simply the work of politicians and capitalists. Oh no
column2: the common man is every bit as guilty; otherwise
column3: people and nations would have re- belled long ago! There's a destructive urge in people
column4: the urge to rage
column5: murder and kill. And until all of humanity
column6: without exception
column7: undergoes a metamorphosis
column8: wars will continue to be waged
column9: and everything that has been carefully built up
column10: cultivated and grown will be cut down and destroyed
column11: only to start allover again!

column1: I've often been down in the dumps
column2: but never desperate. I look upon our life in hiding as an interesting adventure
column3: full of danger and romance
column4: and every privation as an amusing addition to my diary. I've made up my mind to lead a different life from other girls
column5: and not to become an ordinary housewife later on. What I'm experiencing here is a good beginning to an interesting life
column6: and that's the reason-the only reason-why I have to laugh at the humorous side of the most dangerous moments.

column1: I'm young and have many hidden qualities; I'm young and strong and living through a big adventure; I'm right in the middle of it and can't spend all day complaining because it's impossible to have any fun! I'm blessed with many things: happiness
column2: a cheerful disposition and strength. Every day I feel myself maturing
column3: I feel liberation drawing near
column4: I feel the beauty of nature and the goodness of the people around me. Every day I think what a fascinating and amusing adventure this is! With all that
column5: why should I despair?

column1: Yours
column2: Anne M. Frank

column2: MAY 7

column1: Dearest Kitty
Father and I had a long talk yesterday afternoon. I cried my eyes out
column2: and he cried too. Do you know what he said to me
column3: Kitty?

column1: ""I've received many letters in my lifetime
column2: but none as hurtful as this. You
column3: who have had so much love from your parents. You
column4: whose parents have always been ready to help you
column5: who have always defended you
column6: no matter what. You talk of not having to account to us for your actions! You feel you've been wronged and left to your own devices. No
column7: Anne
column8: you've done us a great injustice! ""Perhaps you didn't mean it that way
column9: but that's what you wrote. No
column10: Anne
column11: we have done nothing to deserve such a reproach!""

column1: Oh
column2: I've failed miserably. This is the worst thing I've ever done in my entire life. I used my tears to show off
column3: to make myself seem important so he'd respect me. I've certainly had my share of unhappiness
column4: and everything I said about Mother is true. But to accuse Pim
column5: who's so good and who's done everything for me-no
column6: that was too cruel for words.

column1: It's good that somebody has finally cut me down to size
column2: has broken my pride
column3: because I've been far too smug. Not everything Mistress Anne does is good! Anyone who deliberately causes such pain to someone they say they love is despicable
column4: the lowest of the low!

column1: What I'm most ashamed of is the way Father has forgiven me; he said he's going to throw the letter in the stove
column2: and he's being so nice to me now
column3: as if he were the one who'd done something wrong. Well
column4: Anne
column5: you still have a lot to learn. It's time you made a beginning
column6: in- stead of looking down at others and always giving them the blame!

column1: I've known a lot of sorrow
column2: but who hasn't at my age? I've been putting on an act
column3: but was hardly even aware of it. I've felt lonely
column4: but never desperate! Not like Father
column5: who once ran out into the street with a knife so he could put an end to it all. I've never gone that far.

column1: I should be deeply ashamed of myself
column2: and I am. What's done can't be undone
column3: but at least you can keep it from happening again. I'd like to start all over
column4: and that shouldn't be difficult
column5: now that I have Peter. With him supporting me
column6: I know I can do it! I'm not alone anymore. He loves me
column7: I love him
column8: I have my books
column9: my writing and my diary. I'm not all that ugly
column10: or that stupid
column11: I have a sunny disposition
column12: and I want to develop a good character!

column1: Yes
column2: Anne
column3: you knew full well that your letter was unkind and untrue
column4: but you were actually proud of it! I'll take Father as my example once again
column5: and I will improve myself.

column1: Yours

column1: Miep sent us a raisin bread with ""Happy Pentecost"" written on top. It's almost as if she were mocking us
column2: since our moods and cares are far from ""happy."" We've all become more frightened since the van Hoeven business. Once again you hear ""shh"" from all I sides
column3: and we're doing everything more quietly. The police forced the door there; they could just as easily do that here too! What will we do if we're ever. . . no
column4: I mustn't write that down. But the question won't let itself be pushed to the back of my mind today; on the contrary
column5: all the fear I've ever felt is looming before me in all its horror.

column1: I had to go downstairs alone at eight this evening to use the bathroom. There was no one down there
column2: since they were all listening to the radio. I wanted to be brave
column3: but it was hard. I always feel safer upstairs than in that huge
column4: silent house; when I'm alone with those mysterious muffied sounds from upstairs and the honking of horns in the street
column5: I have to hurry and remind myself where I am to keep from getting the shivers.

column1: Miep has been acting much nicer toward us since her talk with Father. But I haven't told you about that yet. Miep came up one afternoon all flushed and asked Father straight out if we thought they too were infected with the current anti-Semitism. Father was stunned and quickly talked her out of the idea
column2: but some of Miep's suspicion has lingered on. They're doing more errands for us now and showing more of an interest in our troubles
column3: though we certainly shouldn't bother them with our woes. Oh
column4: they're such good
column5: noble people!

column1: I've asked myself again and again whether it wouldn't have been better if we hadn't gone into hiding
column2: if we were dead now and didn't have to go through this misery
column3: especially so that the others could be spared the burden. But we all shrink from this thought. We still love life
column4: we haven't yet forgotten the voice of nature
column5: and we keep hoping
column6: hoping for. . . everything. Let something happen soon
column7: even an air raid. Nothing can be more crushing than this anxiety. Let the end come
column8: however cruel; at least then we'll know whether we are to be the victors or the vanquished.

column1: Yours
column2: Anne M. Frank
